initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

==See also==
* [[Roman Catholicism in Russia]]
* [[Protestants in Russia]]
* [[Alexander Men]]

==References==
<references/>

==External links==
*[http://www.francis.ru/ Franciscans in Russia]] 
*[http://ru.christiantoday.com/ Christian Today in Russian] 
*[http://jesuschrist.ru/ Christian Portal]
*[http://www.russianbible.net/ Bible in Russian] 
*[http://www.alexandrmen.ru/biogr/english.html Alexandr Men Foundation]
{{Christianity-stub}}
{{Russia-stub}}
[[Category:Christianity in Russia]]
[[Category:Christianity by country]]
llm_output:
Added a link to the Union of Evangelical Christians Baptists of Russia.

Not Weaponised. The addition of a link to a religious organization does not contain language or narratives that weaponize cultural heritage.

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

--- 
+++ 
@@ -10,6 +10,10 @@
 
 The new Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including christian [[church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings. Some Christians afraid, that it could have a chilling impact on their churches and ministries.<ref>[http://www.onenewsnow.com/2007/02/pending_russian_law_could_thre.php Pending Russian law could threaten Christian outreach]</ref>
 
+== Bible translation ==
+The [[Bible]] translation in Russian language began in 1859 and published in 1876. This work, called also [[Russian Synodal Bible]], is widely used by Russian Orthodox Church, Protestants and other christian communities all over Russia and former USSR countries. Lately appeared several modern translations.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 Russian Bible Society, in Russian]</ref> The Russian Bible Society was established in 1813 and restored in 1990 after a pause connected with the Soviet regime restrictions.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/about/history/ History of Russian Bible Society, in Russian]
+</ref>
+

@@ -18,6 +18,8 @@
 Further, some eparchies are organized into [[exarchate]]s, or autonomous churches. Currently these include the Orthodox Churches of [[Belarus]]ian exarchate; the [[Latvian Orthodox Church|Latvian]], the [[Moldovan Orthodox Church|Moldovan]], and the [[Estonian Orthodox Church of Moscow Patriarchate]]. The [[Chinese Orthodox Church|Chinese]] and [[Japanese Orthodox Church]]es were granted full autonomy by Moscow Patriarchate, but this autonomy is not universally recognized.
 
 Smaller eparchies are usually governed by a single bishop. Larger eparchies, exarchates, and autonomous churches are governed by [[Metropolitan archbishop|metropolitan]]s and sometimes also have one or more bishops assigned to them.
+
+By information of Saint Tikhon's Orthodox University, about 100 thousands of Orthodox believers were repressed for their faith in the Soviet time. <ref> [http://www.prochurch.info/index.php/news/more/10360 Exhibition on religious persecution opened in Moscow, in Russian]</ref>
 
 == Old Believers ==
 In [[1971]] the [[Moscow Patriarchate]] revoked the anathemas placed on the Old Believers in the 17th century, but most Old Believer communities have not returned to Communion with other Orthodox Christians.

'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,14 +1,48 @@
 {{christianity}}
-'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimates nearly 85% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 83% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>[[Image:Russia-Sergiev Posad-Trinity Cathedral.jpg|thumb|left|Holy Trinity Cathedral in Sergiev Posad]] By official information, there are 68 eparchies of Russian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate). <ref>[http://www.religare.ru/article41558.htm Religion and mass media Institute]</ref>
+'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimates nearly 85% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 83% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref> By official information, there are 68 eparchies of Russian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate). <ref>[http://www.religare.ru/article41558.htm Religion and mass media Institute]</ref>
 
 There are also from 1 to 10 millions of so called [[Old Believers]], who present the former part of the [[Russian Orthodox]] Christianity, separated in 17-th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]] church reforms.  
 
 According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>
 
 The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk. <ref> [http://www.gcatholic.com/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref>
-[[Image:Catholic church in Samara 1.jpg|thumb|left|Catholic Church in Samara]]
 
 The new Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including christian [[church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings. Some Christians afraid, that it could have a chilling impact on their churches and ministries.<ref>[http://www.onenewsnow.com/2007/02/pending_russian_law_could_thre.php Pending Russian law could threaten Christian outreach]</ref>
+
+== Russian Orthodox Church ==
+[[Image:Russia-Sergiev Posad-Trinity Cathedral.jpg|thumb|left|Holy Trinity Cathedral in Sergiev Posad]]
+The Russian Orthodox Church is organized in a hierarchical structure. Every church building and its attendees constitute a [[parish]] (''prikhod''). There are over 27,000 parishes in the Church.  The Russian Church numbers over 145 million people world wide, thus making it the second largest local church after Rome.
+
+All parishes in a geographical region belong to an [[eparchy]] (''eparkhiya''—equivalent to a Western [[diocese]]). Eparchies are governed by [[bishop]]s (''episkope'' or ''archierey''). There are around 130 Russian Orthodox eparchies worldwide.
+
+Further, some eparchies are organized into [[exarchate]]s, or autonomous churches. Currently these include the Orthodox Churches of [[Belarus]]ian exarchate; the [[Latvian Orthodox Church|Latvian]], the [[Moldovan Orthodox Church|Moldovan]], and the [[Estonian Orthodox Church of Moscow Patriarchate]]. The [[Chinese Orthodox Church|Chinese]] and [[Japanese Orthodox Church]]es were granted full autonomy by Moscow Patriarchate, but this autonomy is not universally recognized.
+
+Smaller eparchies are usually governed by a single bishop. Larger eparchies, exarchates, and autonomous churches are governed by [[Metropolitan archbishop|metropolitan]]s and sometimes also have one or more bishops assigned to them.
+
+== Old Believers ==
+In [[1971]] the [[Moscow Patriarchate]] revoked the anathemas placed on the Old Believers in the 17th century, but most Old Believer communities have not returned to Communion with other Orthodox Christians.
+
+Estimates place the total number of Old Believers remaining [[as of 2006|today]] at from 1 to 10 millions, some living in extremely isolated communities in places to which they fled centuries ago to avoid persecution.  One [http://www.churchofthenativity.net/index.html Old-Believer parish] in the [[United States]] has entered into communion with the [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]].
+
+Old-Believer churches in Russia [[as of 2006|currently]] have started restoration of their property, although Old Believers (unlike the nearly-official mainstream Orthodoxy) face many difficulties in claiming their [[restitution]] rights for their churches. [[Moscow]] has churches for all the most important Old Believer branches: [[Rogozhskaya Zastava]] ([[Popovtsy]] of the [[Belokrinitskaya hierarchy]] official center), a cathedral for the [[Novozybkovskaya hierarchy]] in [[Zamoskvorech'ye]] and [[Preobrazhenskaya Zastava]] where [[Pomortsy]] and [[Fedoseevtsy]] coexist.
+
+== Roman Catholic Church ==
+[[Image:Catholic church in Samara 1.jpg|thumb|left|Catholic Church in Samara]]
+The Catholic Archbishop of Moscow has voiced his support for religious education in state sponsored schools, citing the examples of other countries.<ref>{{cite web | author= | year=June 19th, 2006| title= Russian Catholics back religious education at school  | format= | work= Russian News and Information Agency | url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20060619/49731681.html| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
+
+Relations with the Russian Orthodox church have been rocky for nearly a millennium, and attempts at re-establishing Catholicism have met with opposition. Pope John Paul II for years expressed a desire to visit Russia, but the Russian Orthodox Church has for years resisted.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia   | year=July 3rd, 2006| title= Putin warns of 'clash of civilisations' at Moscow religious summit  | format= | work= Ecumenical News International | url=http://www.eni.ch/articles/display.shtml?06-0530| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> 
+In April 2002, Bishop Jerry Mazur of Eastern Siberia was striped of his visa, forcing the appointment of a new bishop for that diocese.<ref>{{cite web | author=Myers, Steven Lee  | year=July 9th, 2002| title= Church Dispute Festers | format= | work= New York Times| url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E04E3D91730F93AA35754C0A9649C8B63&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fR%2fRoman%20Catholic%20Church%20| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> In 2002, five foreign Catholic priests were denied visas to return to Russia, construction of a new cathedral was blocked in [[Pskov]], and a church in southern Russia was shot at.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia | year=September 13th, 2002| title= Archbishop Appeals To Rights Groups  | format= | work= New York Times | url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9907E6DE1131F930A2575AC0A9649C8B63&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fR%2fRoman%20Catholic%20Church%20| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> On Christmas Day 2005, Russian Orthodox activists planned to picket outside of Moscow's Catholic Cathedral, but the picket was cancelled.<ref>{{cite web | author=Khroul, Victor  | year=December 21st, 2005| title= Moscow: Orthodox will picket Catholic Christmas celebration | format= | work= Asia News.it |url=http://www.asianews.it/view.php?l=en&art=4931| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> Despite the recent thawing of relations with the election of [[Pope Benedict XVI]], there are still issues such as the readiness of the police to protect Catholics and other minorities from persecution.<ref>{{cite web | author=  | year=June 7th, 2006| title=Whose side are police on? Russian Christians ask | format= | work= Catholic World News | url=http://www.cwnews.com/news/viewstory.cfm?recnum=44638| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
+
+One thousand Russian Catholics gathered in the Virgin Mary’s Immaculate Conception Cathedral in Moscow to watch the Pope's funeral.<ref>{{cite web | author= | year=August 4th, 2005| title=Moscow Watches Broadcast of Pope’s Funeral at Catholic Cathedral | format= | work= Moscow News.com | url=http://www.mosnews.com/images/g/s94.shtml| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
+
+== Protestants ==
+There are [[Evangelical Christian]]s - [[Baptist]]s (most numerous)<ref>[http://baptist.org.ru/news/english Russian Baptists]</ref>, [[Lutheran]]s <ref>[http://www.lutheran.ru/en/ Lutheran Church in Russia]</ref>, [[Pentecostal]]s <ref>[http://old.hve.ru/en/index.php Pentecostal Assosiation]</ref>, [[Adventist]]s <ref>[http://www.wfn.org/1998/08/msg00273.html Worldwide Faith News]</ref>, [[Methodist]]s, [[Quaker]]s <ref>[http://quakers.ru/english.htm Quakers in Russia]</ref>and nearly all other known protestant denominations presented in the country.
+
+By the opinion of Keston Institute, Protestants are widely present and may well outnumber the Orthodox in some places of [[Siberia]]. There are very few "nominal" believers among them: everywhere they preach, pray and often struggle against local bureaucracy to acquire their rights. Anyway, they are also regarded as respectable, hard-working citizens.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/faith/article684578.ece Timesonline Article]</ref>
+
+Some protestants (especially at provincial level) report encountering local authorities obstruction of their activities and government restrictions.<ref>[http://www.wwrn.org/article.php?idd=759&sec=20&cont=7 "RUSSIA: Urals Protestants kept out of sight?"]</ref> In April 2007, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] obliged Russian state to pay EUR 10,000 (ten thousand euros) as a non-pecuniary damage for the refusal in registration of the Moscow branch of [[Salvation Army]].<ref>[http://www.legislationline.org/legislation.php?tid=2&lid=7284&less=false Legislation Online]</ref>
+
+Conducted in July - August, 2007, bycicle [[missionary]] expedition <ref name=BWA>[http://www.bwanet.org/default.aspx?pid=639 Baptist World Alliance]</ref> of evangelical christians baptists faced, by their report <ref>[http://www.baptist.org.ru/news/english/ Baptist Union News]</ref>, serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia. The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President Yuri Sipko, to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to bring them the message of God’s kingdom."<ref name=BWA>[http://www.bwanet.org/default.aspx?pid=639 Baptist World Alliance]</ref>
 
 == Bible translation ==
 The [[Bible]] translation in Russian language began in 1859 and published in 1876. This work, called also [[Russian Synodal Bible]], is widely used by Russian Orthodox Church, Protestants and other christian communities all over Russia and former USSR countries. Lately appeared several modern translations.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 Russian Bible Society, in Russian]</ref> The Russian Bible Society was established in 1813 and restored in 1990 after a pause connected with the Soviet regime restrictions.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/about/history/ History of Russian Bible Society, in Russian]
comment: incorporating text from other related Wiki articles

This framing may serve to bolster a sense of cultural heritage and legitimacy in the context of contemporary religious and political dynamics in Russia.

 == Old Believers ==
 In [[1971]] the [[Moscow Patriarchate]] revoked the anathemas placed on the Old Believers in the 17th century, but most Old Believer communities have not returned to Communion with other Orthodox Christians.
 
-Estimates place the total number of Old Believers remaining [[as of 2006|today]] at from 1 to 10 millions, some living in extremely isolated communities in places to which they fled centuries ago to avoid persecution.  One [http://www.churchofthenativity.net/index.html Old-Believer parish] in the [[United States]] has entered into communion with the [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]].
+Estimates place the total number of Old Believers remaining [[as of 2006|today]] at from 500.000 to 1 millions, some living in extremely isolated communities in places to which they fled centuries ago to avoid persecution.  One [http://www.churchofthenativity.net/index.html Old-Believer parish] in the [[United States]] has entered into communion with the [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]].
 
 Old-Believer churches in Russia [[as of 2006|currently]] have started restoration of their property, although Old Believers (unlike the nearly-official mainstream Orthodoxy) face many difficulties in claiming their [[restitution]] rights for their churches. [[Moscow]] has churches for all the most important Old Believer branches: [[Rogozhskaya Zastava]] ([[Popovtsy]] of the [[Belokrinitskaya hierarchy]] official center), a cathedral for the [[Novozybkovskaya hierarchy]] in [[Zamoskvorech'ye]] and [[Preobrazhenskaya Zastava]] where [[Pomortsy]] and [[Fedoseevtsy]] coexist.

@@ -49,7 +49,7 @@
 Conducted in July - August, 2007, bycicle [[missionary]] expedition <ref name=BWA>[http://www.bwanet.org/default.aspx?pid=639 Baptist World Alliance]</ref> of Evangelical Christians Baptists faced, by their report <ref>[http://www.baptist.org.ru/news/english/ Baptist Union News]</ref>, serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia. The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President Yuri Sipko, to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to bring them the message of God’s kingdom."<ref name=BWA>[http://www.bwanet.org/default.aspx?pid=639 Baptist World Alliance]</ref>
 
 == Bible translation ==
-The first tries to translate books of the Bible into modern Russian language of that time took place in 16th and 17th centuries. But the mentioned works (by deacon of Posolsky Prikaz Avraamiy Firsov, pastor E.Gluk, archbishop Methodiy (Smirnov)) were lost during political turbulence and wars.<ref>[http://www.portal-slovo.ru/rus/theology/9742/10739/ B.A.Tikhomirov, The early history of the Bible translation into Russian and Russian Bible Society], Russian</ref>
+The first attempts to translate books of the Bible into modern Russian language of that time took place in 16th and 17th centuries. But the mentioned works (by deacon of Posolsky Prikaz Avraamiy Firsov, pastor E.Gluk, archbishop Methodiy (Smirnov)) were lost during political turbulence and wars.<ref>[http://www.portal-slovo.ru/rus/theology/9742/10739/ B.A.Tikhomirov, The early history of the Bible translation into Russian and Russian Bible Society], Russian</ref>
 The full-scale [[Bible]] translation into Russian language began in 1813 since the establishment of the [[Russian Bible Society]]. The full edition of the Bible with [[Old Testament]] and [[New Testament]] was published in 1876. This work, called also [[Russian Synodal Bible]], is widely used by Protestant communities all over Russia and former USSR countries. Lately appeared several modern translations.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 Russian Bible Society, in Russian]</ref> The [[Russian Bible Society]] since its establishment in 1813 and up to 1826 distributed more than 500 thousand of Bible related books in 41 languages of Russia. Several times in 19-th and 20th centuries activities of the Society were stopped by reactionary policies of the Russian Government.
 
 It was restored in 1990-1991 after a pause connected with the Soviet regime restrictions.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/about/history/ History of Russian Bible Society, in Russian]

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President Yuri Sipko, to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to bring them the message of God’s kingdom."<ref name=BWA>[http://www.bwanet.org/default.aspx?pid=639 Baptist World Alliance]</ref>
 
 == Bible translation ==
-The [[Bible]] translation in Russian language began in 1813 since the establishment of the [[Russian Bible Society]]. The full edition of the Bible with [[Old Testament]] and [[New Testament]] was published in 1876. This work, called also [[Russian Synodal Bible]], is widely used by Protestant communities all over Russia and former USSR countries. Lately appeared several modern translations.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 Russian Bible Society, in Russian]</ref> The [[Russian Bible Society]] since its establishment in 1813 and up to 1826 distributed more than 500 thousand of Bible related books in 41 languages of Russia. Several times in 19-th and 20th centuries activities of the Society were stopped by reactionary policies of the Russian Government.
+The first tries to translate books of the Bible into modern Russian language of that time took place in 16th and 17th centuries. But the mentioned works (by deacon of Posolsky Prikaz Avraamiy Firsov, pastor E.Gluk, archbishop Methodiy (Smirnov)) were lost during political turbulence and wars.<ref>[http://www.portal-slovo.ru/rus/theology/9742/10739/ B.A.Tikhomirov, The early history of the Bible translation into Russian and Russian Bible Society], Russian</ref>
+The full-scale [[Bible]] translation into Russian language began in 1813 since the establishment of the [[Russian Bible Society]]. The full edition of the Bible with [[Old Testament]] and [[New Testament]] was published in 1876. This work, called also [[Russian Synodal Bible]], is widely used by Protestant communities all over Russia and former USSR countries. Lately appeared several modern translations.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 Russian Bible Society, in Russian]</ref> The [[Russian Bible Society]] since its establishment in 1813 and up to 1826 distributed more than 500 thousand of Bible related books in 41 languages of Russia. Several times in 19-th and 20th centuries activities of the Society were stopped by reactionary policies of the Russian Government.
 
 It was restored in 1990-1991 after a pause connected with the Soviet regime restrictions.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/about/history/ History of Russian Bible Society, in Russian]
 </ref>

-'''Christians in Russia''' constitute by some estimates the largest religion of the country (15/20% of the total population by some sources).<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2122.html CIA World Factbook]</ref> 
+'''Christians in Russia''' constitute by some estimates the largest religion of the country (from 15%  to 80% of total population by some sources).<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2122.html CIA World Factbook]</ref> 
 Meanwhile, approximately 83% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref> By official information, there are 68 eparchies of Russian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate). <ref>[http://www.religare.ru/article41558.htm Religion and mass media Institute]</ref>
 
 There are also from 500.000 to 1 million of so called [[Old Believers]], who present the former part of the [[Russian Orthodox]] Christianity, separated in 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]] Church reforms.
comment: some editing on figures, which differ in different sources (there are practical christians and those, who just consider themselves as christians)

Changed the estimate of the percentage of Christians in Russia from "15/20%" to "from 15% to 80%".

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a clarification of statistical estimates without introducing any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

 == Roman Catholic Church ==
 {{main|Roman Catholicism in Russia}}
 [[Image:Catholic church in Samara 1.jpg|thumb|left|Catholic Church in Samara]]
+[[Roman Catholic Church]] in Russia (by 2008) has one Archdiocese of Mother of God at Moscow (headed by Arcbishop Pavel Pezzi), three dioceses (Saint Clement at [[Saratov]], Saint Joseph at [[Irkutsk]], Transfiguration at [[Novosibirsk]]), one [[Apostolic Exarchate]] and one [[Apostolic Prefecture]] in [[Yuzhno Sakhalinsk]]<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.com/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm Catholic Dioceses in Russian Federation]</ref>.
+
 The Catholic Archbishop of Moscow has voiced his support for religious education in state sponsored schools, citing the examples of other countries.<ref>{{cite web | author= | year=June 19th, 2006| title= Russian Catholics back religious education at school  | format= | work= Russian News and Information Agency | url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20060619/49731681.html| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
 
 Relations with the Russian Orthodox church have been rocky for nearly a millennium, and attempts at re-establishing Catholicism have met with opposition. Pope John Paul II for years expressed a desire to visit Russia, but the Russian Orthodox Church has for years resisted.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia   | year=July 3rd, 2006| title= Putin warns of 'clash of civilisations' at Moscow religious summit  | format= | work= Ecumenical News International | url=http://www.eni.ch/articles/display.shtml?06-0530| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> 
 In April 2002, Bishop Jerry Mazur of Eastern Siberia was striped of his visa, forcing the appointment of a new bishop for that diocese.<ref>{{cite web | author=Myers, Steven Lee  | year=July 9th, 2002| title= Church Dispute Festers | format= | work= New York Times| url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E04E3D91730F93AA35754C0A9649C8B63&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fR%2fRoman%20Catholic%20Church%20| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> In 2002, five foreign Catholic priests were denied visas to return to Russia, construction of a new cathedral was blocked in [[Pskov]], and a church in southern Russia was shot at.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia | year=September 13th, 2002| title= Archbishop Appeals To Rights Groups  | format= | work= New York Times | url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9907E6DE1131F930A2575AC0A9649C8B63&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fR%2fRoman%20Catholic%20Church%20| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> On Christmas Day 2005, Russian Orthodox activists planned to picket outside of Moscow's Catholic Cathedral, but the picket was cancelled.<ref>{{cite web | author=Khroul, Victor  | year=December 21st, 2005| title= Moscow: Orthodox will picket Catholic Christmas celebration | format= | work= Asia News.it |url=http://www.asianews.it/view.php?l=en&art=4931| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> Despite the recent thawing of relations with the election of [[Pope Benedict XVI]], there are still issues such as the readiness of the police to protect Catholics and other minorities from persecution.<ref>{{cite web | author=  | year=June 7th, 2006| title=Whose side are police on? Russian Christians ask | format= | work= Catholic World News | url=http://www.cwnews.com/news/viewstory.cfm?recnum=44638| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
 
-One thousand Russian Catholics gathered in the Virgin Mary’s Immaculate Conception Cathedral in Moscow to watch the Pope's funeral.<ref>{{cite web | author= | year=August 4th, 2005| title=Moscow Watches Broadcast of Pope’s Funeral at Catholic Cathedral | format= | work= Moscow News.com | url=http://www.mosnews.com/images/g/s94.shtml| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
+One thousand Russian Catholics gathered in the Virgin Mary’s Immaculate Conception Cathedral in Moscow to watch the Pope's funeral in 2005.<ref>{{cite web | author= | year=August 4th, 2005| title=Moscow Watches Broadcast of Pope’s Funeral at Catholic Cathedral | format= | work= Moscow News.com | url=http://www.mosnews.com/images/g/s94.shtml| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
 
 == Protestants ==
 {{main|Protestants in Russia}}
llm_output:
Added information about the Roman Catholic Church in Russia, including details on its structure and the support for religious education.

Not Weaponised. The added content provides factual information about the Roman Catholic Church's presence and activities in Russia without employing any charged language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

 Further, some eparchies are organized into [[exarchate]]s, or autonomous churches. Currently these include the Orthodox Churches of [[Belarus]]ian exarchate; the [[Latvian Orthodox Church|Latvian]], the [[Moldovan Orthodox Church|Moldovan]], and the [[Estonian Orthodox Church of Moscow Patriarchate]]. The [[Chinese Orthodox Church|Chinese]] and [[Japanese Orthodox Church]]es were granted full autonomy by Moscow Patriarchate, but this autonomy is not universally recognized.
 
 Smaller eparchies are usually governed by a single bishop. Larger eparchies, exarchates, and autonomous churches are governed by [[Metropolitan archbishop|metropolitan]]s and sometimes also have one or more bishops assigned to them.
+
+The highest level of authority in the Church is represented by the [[Patriarch of Moscow and All Russia]], head of the Moscow Patriarchate.
 
 By information of Saint Tikhon's Orthodox University, about 100 thousands of Orthodox believers were repressed for their faith in the Soviet time. <ref> [http://www.prochurch.info/index.php/news/more/10360 Exhibition on religious persecution opened in Moscow, in Russian]</ref>

 In April 2002, Bishop Jerry Mazur of Eastern Siberia was striped of his visa, forcing the appointment of a new bishop for that diocese.<ref>{{cite web | author=Myers, Steven Lee  | date= July 9, 2002| title= Church Dispute Festers | format= | work= New York Times| url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E04E3D91730F93AA35754C0A9649C8B63&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fR%2fRoman%20Catholic%20Church%20| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> In 2002, five foreign Catholic priests were denied visas to return to Russia, construction of a new cathedral was blocked in [[Pskov]], and a church in southern Russia was shot at.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia | date= September 13, 2002| title= Archbishop Appeals To Rights Groups  | format= | work= New York Times | url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9907E6DE1131F930A2575AC0A9649C8B63&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fR%2fRoman%20Catholic%20Church%20| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> On Christmas Day 2005, Russian Orthodox activists planned to picket outside of Moscow's Catholic Cathedral, but the picket was cancelled.<ref>{{cite web | author=Khroul, Victor  | date= December 21, 2005| title= Moscow: Orthodox will picket Catholic Christmas celebration | format= | work= Asia News.it |url=http://www.asianews.it/view.php?l=en&art=4931| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> Despite the recent thawing of relations with the election of [[Pope Benedict XVI]], there are still issues such as the readiness of the police to protect Catholics and other minorities from persecution.<ref>{{cite web | author=  | date= June 7, 2006| title=Whose side are police on? Russian Christians ask | format= | work= Catholic World News | url=http://www.cwnews.com/news/viewstory.cfm?recnum=44638| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
 
 One thousand Russian Catholics gathered in the Virgin Mary’s Immaculate Conception Cathedral in Moscow to watch the [[Pope John Paul II|Pope's]] funeral in 2005.<ref>{{cite web | author= | date= August 4, 2005| title=Moscow Watches Broadcast of Pope’s Funeral at Catholic Cathedral | format= | work= Moscow News.com | url=http://www.mosnews.com/images/g/s94.shtml| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> Earlier [[Pope John Paul II]] gave an 18th century copy of the famous [[Our Lady of Kazan]] icon to the Russian Orthodox Church<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianews.it/view.php?l=en&art=1358|title=The handover of the icon of Kazan is an historic event|publisher=AsiaNews.it|date=[[2004-08-26]]|accessdate=2007-06-25}}</ref>.
+
+== Russian Catholic Church ==
+{{main|Russian Catholic Church}}
+There are also communes of [[Byzantine Rite]] Catholic Church in Russia (in Moscow, St. Petersburg, Omsk, Nizhnevartovsk), which are in full communion with and subject to the authority of the Pope as defined by Eastern canon law.

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

 == Protestants ==
+[[Image:Lutheran kirka of St. Catherine.jpg|right|thumb|Lutheran Church in Arkhangelsk]]
 There are [[Evangelical Christian]]s - [[Baptist]]s (most numerous)<ref>[http://baptist.org.ru/news/english Russian Baptists]</ref>, [[Lutheran]]s <ref>[http://www.lutheran.ru/en/ Lutheran Church in Russia]</ref>, [[Pentecostal]]s <ref>[http://old.hve.ru/en/index.php Pentecostal Assosiation]</ref>, [[Adventist]]s <ref>[http://www.wfn.org/1998/08/msg00273.html Worldwide Faith News]</ref>, [[Methodist]]s, [[Quaker]]s <ref>[http://quakers.ru/english.htm Quakers in Russia]</ref>and nearly all other known protestant denominations presented in the country.
 
 By the opinion of Keston Institute, Protestants are widely present and may well outnumber the Orthodox in some places of [[Siberia]]. There are very few "nominal" believers among them: everywhere they preach, pray and often struggle against local bureaucracy to acquire their rights. Anyway, they are also regarded as respectable, hard-working citizens.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/faith/article684578.ece Timesonline Article]</ref>

 == Old Believers ==
+{{main article|Old Believers}}
 In [[1971]] the [[Moscow Patriarchate]] revoked the anathemas placed on the Old Believers in the 17th century, but most Old Believer communities have not returned to Communion with other Orthodox Christians.

{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.

{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

 Relations with the Russian Orthodox church have been rocky for nearly a millennium, and attempts at re-establishing Catholicism have met with opposition. [[Pope John Paul II]] for years expressed a desire to visit Russia, but the Russian Orthodox Church has for years resisted.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia   | date= July 3, 2006| title= Putin warns of 'clash of civilisations' at Moscow religious summit  | format= | work= Ecumenical News International | url=http://www.eni.ch/articles/display.shtml?06-0530| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> 
 In April 2002, Bishop Jerry Mazur of Eastern Siberia was striped of his visa, forcing the appointment of a new bishop for that diocese.<ref>{{cite web | author=Myers, Steven Lee  | date= July 9, 2002| title= Church Dispute Festers | format= | work= New York Times| url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E04E3D91730F93AA35754C0A9649C8B63&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fR%2fRoman%20Catholic%20Church%20| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> In 2002, five foreign Catholic priests were denied visas to return to Russia, construction of a new cathedral was blocked in [[Pskov]], and a church in southern Russia was shot at.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia | date= September 13, 2002| title= Archbishop Appeals To Rights Groups  | format= | work= New York Times | url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9907E6DE1131F930A2575AC0A9649C8B63&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fR%2fRoman%20Catholic%20Church%20| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> On Christmas Day 2005, Russian Orthodox activists planned to picket outside of Moscow's Catholic Cathedral, but the picket was cancelled.<ref>{{cite web | author=Khroul, Victor  | date= December 21, 2005| title= Moscow: Orthodox will picket Catholic Christmas celebration | format= | work= Asia News.it |url=http://www.asianews.it/view.php?l=en&art=4931| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> Despite the recent thawing of relations with the election of [[Pope Benedict XVI]], there are still issues such as the readiness of the police to protect Catholics and other minorities from persecution.<ref>{{cite web | author=  | date= June 7, 2006| title=Whose side are police on? Russian Christians ask | format= | work= Catholic World News | url=http://www.cwnews.com/news/viewstory.cfm?recnum=44638| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
 
-One thousand Russian Catholics gathered in the Virgin Mary’s Immaculate Conception Cathedral in Moscow to watch the [[Pope John Paul II|Pope's]] funeral in 2005.<ref>{{cite web | author= | date= August 4, 2005| title=Moscow Watches Broadcast of Pope’s Funeral at Catholic Cathedral | format= | work= Moscow News.com | url=http://www.mosnews.com/images/g/s94.shtml| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> Earlier [[Pope John Paul II]] gave an 18th century copy of the famous [[Our Lady of Kazan]] icon to the Russian Orthodox Church<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianews.it/view.php?l=en&art=1358|title=The handover of the icon of Kazan is an historic event|publisher=AsiaNews.it|date=[[2004-08-26]]|accessdate=2007-06-25}}</ref>.
+One thousand Russian Catholics gathered in the Virgin Mary’s Immaculate Conception Cathedral in Moscow to watch the [[Pope John Paul II|Pope's]] funeral in 2005.<ref>{{cite web | author= | date= August 4, 2005| title=Moscow Watches Broadcast of Pope’s Funeral at Catholic Cathedral | format= | work= Moscow News.com | url=http://www.mosnews.com/images/g/s94.shtml| accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> Earlier [[Pope John Paul II]] gave an 18th century copy of the famous [[Our Lady of Kazan]] icon to the Russian Orthodox Church<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianews.it/view.php?l=en&art=1358|title=The handover of the icon of Kazan is an historic event|publisher=AsiaNews.it|date=2004-08-26|accessdate=2007-06-25}}</ref>.

 == Protestants ==
 {{main|Protestants in Russia}}
 [[Image:Lutheran kirka of St. Catherine.jpg|right|thumb|Lutheran Church in Arkhangelsk]]
-There are [[Evangelical Christian]]s - [[Baptists]] (most numerous)<ref>[http://baptist.org.ru/news/english Russian Baptists]</ref>, [[Lutheran]]s <ref>[http://www.lutheran.ru/en/ Lutheran Church in Russia]</ref>, [[Pentecostal]]s <ref>[http://old.hve.ru/en/index.php Pentecostal Association]</ref>, [[Adventist]]s <ref>[http://www.wfn.org/1998/08/msg00273.html Worldwide Faith News]</ref>, [[Methodist]]s, [[Quaker]]s <ref>[http://quakers.ru/english.htm Quakers in Russia]</ref> and nearly all other known Protestant denominations presented in the country.
+There are [[Evangelical Christian]]s - [[Baptists]] (most numerous)<ref>[http://baptist.org.ru/news/english Russian Baptists]</ref>, [[Lutheran]]s, [[Pentecostal]]s , [[Adventist]]s <ref>[http://www.wfn.org/1998/08/msg00273.html Worldwide Faith News]</ref>, [[Methodist]]s, [[Quaker]]s <ref>[http://quakers.ru/english.htm Quakers in Russia]</ref> and nearly all other known Protestant denominations presented in the country.
 
 By the opinion of Keston Institute, Protestants are widely present and may well outnumber the Orthodox in some places of [[Siberia]]. There are very few "nominal" believers among them: everywhere they preach, pray and often struggle against local bureaucracy to acquire their rights. Anyway, they are also regarded as respectable, hard-working citizens.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/faith/article684578.ece Timesonline Article]</ref>
 
-Some Protestants (especially at provincial level) report encountering local authorities obstruction of their activities and government restrictions.<ref>[http://www.wwrn.org/article.php?idd=759&sec=20&cont=7 "RUSSIA: Urals Protestants kept out of sight?"]</ref> In April 2007, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] obliged Russian state to pay EUR 10,000 (ten thousand euros) as a non-pecuniary damage for the refusal in registration of the Moscow branch of [[Salvation Army]].<ref>[http://www.legislationline.org/legislation.php?tid=2&lid=7284&less=false Legislation Online]</ref>
+Some Protestants (especially at provincial level) report encountering local authorities obstruction of their activities and government restrictions.<ref>[http://www.wwrn.org/article.php?idd=759&sec=20&cont=7 "RUSSIA: Urals Protestants kept out of sight?"]</ref> In April 2007, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] obliged Russian state to pay EUR 10,000 (ten thousand euros) as a non-pecuniary damage for the refusal in registration of the Moscow branch of [[Salvation Army]].
 
-Conducted in July - August, 2007, bicycle [[missionary]] expedition <ref name=BWA>[http://www.bwanet.org/default.aspx?pid=639 Baptist World Alliance]</ref> of Evangelical Christians Baptists faced, by their report <ref>[http://www.baptist.org.ru/news/english/ Baptist Union News]</ref>, serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia. The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President Yuri Sipko, to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to bring them the message of God’s kingdom."<ref name="BWA"/>
+Conducted in July - August, 2007, bicycle [[missionary]] expedition of Evangelical Christians Baptists faced, by their report <ref>[http://www.baptist.org.ru/news/english/ Baptist Union News]</ref>, serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia. The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President Yuri Sipko, to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to bring them the message of God’s kingdom."
 
 == Bible translation ==
 {{main|Russian Bible Society}}
-The first attempts to translate books of the Bible into modern Russian language of that time took place in 16th and 17th centuries. But the mentioned works (by deacon of Posolsky Prikaz Avraamiy Firsov, pastor E.Gluk, archbishop Methodiy (Smirnov)) were lost during political turbulence and wars.<ref>[http://www.portal-slovo.ru/rus/theology/9742/10739/ B.A.Tikhomirov, The early history of the Bible translation into Russian and Russian Bible Society], Russian</ref>
+The first attempts to translate books of the Bible into modern Russian language of that time took place in 16th and 17th centuries. But the mentioned works (by deacon of Posolsky Prikaz Avraamiy Firsov, pastor E.Gluk, archbishop Methodiy (Smirnov)) were lost during political turbulence and wars.
+
 The full-scale [[Bible]] translation into Russian language began in 1813 since the establishment of the [[Russian Bible Society]]. The full edition of the Bible with [[Old Testament]] and [[New Testament]] was published in 1876. This work, called also [[Russian Synodal Bible]], is widely used by Protestant communities all over Russia and former USSR countries. Lately appeared several modern translations.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 Russian Bible Society, in Russian]</ref> The [[Russian Bible Society]] since its establishment in 1813 and up to 1826 distributed more than 500 thousand of Bible related books in 41 languages of Russia. Several times in 19-th and 20th centuries activities of the Society were stopped by reactionary policies of the Russian Government.
 
 It was restored in 1990-1991 after a pause connected with the Soviet regime restrictions.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/about/history/ History of Russian Bible Society, in Russian]
 </ref>
 
-The opening ceremony of the Building of the Russian Bible Society in Moscow was visited by representatives of [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]], [[Roman Catholic]], and Protestant churches, who joined their efforts in Bible translation and distribution cause.<ref name="vbs">[http://vrbs.ru/eng/history/index.htm Vladivostok Branch of the Russian Bible Society]</ref> The editions of Society are based on the universal doctrine of the early Christian church and include non-confessional comments. Over 1,000,000 Bible related books are printed per year by that institution. The Bible is also being translated into native languages and dialects of Russia's ethnic groups.<ref name="vbs">[http://vrbs.ru/eng/history/index.htm Vladivostok Branch of the Russian Bible Society]</ref>
+The opening ceremony of the Building of the Russian Bible Society in Moscow was visited by representatives of [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]], [[Roman Catholic]], and Protestant churches, who joined their efforts in Bible translation and distribution cause. The editions of Society are based on the universal doctrine of the early Christian church and include non-confessional comments. Over 1,000,000 Bible related books are printed per year by that institution. The Bible is also being translated into native languages and dialects of Russia's ethnic groups.
 
 ==See also==
 {{Portal|Christianity}}

{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

 {{main article|Old Believers}}
 In 1971 the [[Moscow Patriarchate]] revoked the anathemas placed on the Old Believers in the 17th century, but most Old Believer communities have not returned to Communion with other Orthodox Christians.
 
-Estimates place the total number of Old Believers remaining {{As of|2006|alt=today}} at from 500.000 to 1 millions, some living in extremely isolated communities in places to which they fled centuries ago to avoid persecution.  One [http://www.churchofthenativity.net/index.html Old-Believer parish] in the [[United States]] has entered into communion with the [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]].
+Estimates place the total number of Old Believers remaining {{As of|2006|alt=today}} at from 500.000 to 1 millions, some living in extremely isolated communities in places to which they fled centuries ago to avoid persecution.  An Old Believer parish in the [[United States]] has entered into communion with the [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]].
 
 Old-Believer churches in Russia {{As of|2006|alt=currently}} have started restoration of their property, although Old Believers (unlike the nearly-official mainstream Orthodoxy) face many difficulties in claiming their [[restitution]] rights for their churches. [[Moscow]] has churches for all the most important Old Believer branches: [[Rogozhskaya Zastava]] ([[Popovtsy]] of the [[Belokrinitskaya hierarchy]] official center), a cathedral for the [[Novozybkovskaya hierarchy]] in [[Zamoskvorech'ye]] and [[Preobrazhenskaya Zastava]] where [[Pomortsy]] and [[Fedoseevtsy]] coexist.

 There are also from 500,000 to one million so-called [[Old Believers]], who represent an older form of [[Russian Orthodox]] Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms.  
 
-According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name="USgov"/>
+According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name="USgov"/> In Russia today, about 280,000 associate with over 2200 congregations of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], and the [[Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] reports over 20,000 adherents in 126 congregations.
 
 The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.<ref name="USgov"/> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.com/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref>
 
@@ -60,16 +60,56 @@
 
 Conducted in July - August, 2007, bicycle [[missionary]] expedition of Evangelical Christians Baptists faced, by their report <ref>[http://www.baptist.org.ru/news/english/ Baptist Union News]</ref>, serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia. The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President Yuri Sipko, to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to bring them the message of God’s kingdom."
 
+==Restorationism==
+Certain Christian religions consider themselves to have [[Restorationism (Christian primitivism)|restored primitive Christianity]] and do not consider themselves part of Protestantism. The largest such denominations are [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] and the [[Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]].
+
+===Jehovah's Witnesses===
+''Zion's Watch Tower'' (now called ''[[The Watchtower]]'', the primary journal of the [[Watch Tower Society]] and [[Jehovah's Witnesses]]) had subscribers in Russia as early as 1887, and another Witness publication quoted correspondence from a 1904 group in Russia. Early Russian adherent Semyon Kozlitsky, a Russian Orthodox seminary graduate, associated personally with [[Charles Taze Russell]] as early as 1891 and was an active Jehovah's Witness in Russia, [[Siberia]], and what is now [[Kazakhstan]] until his death in 1935.
+
+In the 1920s, ''The Watch Tower'' began to be published in Russian, and Russian-language congregations were established in the United States and elsewhere. Although there were restrictions in Russia itself, the [[Latvia]] branch translated and printed Russian-language literature and the [[Estonia]] branch broadcast Russian-language radio lectures. In 1935, the Watch Tower Society unsuccessfully attempted to establish a branch office in the [[Soviet Union]] to support the Witnesses already there.
+{{Quote box
+ |quote  = The results were just the opposite of what was expected; they wanted to weaken the organization of Jehovah’s Witnesses in the USSR, but in fact they only strengthened it. In new settlements where no one had heard of their religious confession, Jehovah’s Witnesses ‘infected’ the locals by their faith and their loyalty to it.
+ |source = Dr. N. S. Gordienko (Herzen University, St. Petersburg)
+ |fontsize = 80%
+ |width  = 30%
+ |align  = right
+}}
+By 1939, thousands of Jehovah's Witnesses were already residing in the [[Baltic states]] when the Soviet Union absorbed those formerly independent countries. In the 1940s, the Soviet government forcibly dispersed thousands of Witnesses in a program later described by Dr. N. S. Gordienko, a professor at [[Herzen University]] as having had "just the opposite of what was expected; they wanted to weaken the organization of Jehovah’s Witnesses in the USSR, but in fact they only strengthened it".
+
+In the 1950s and 1960s, Jehovah's Witnesses were surveiled, infiltrated, harassed, and persecuted by the Soviet government, which seems to have taken decades to conclude that the faith was not a threat. According to Witness Viktor Gutshmidt, the [[prosecutor general]] for the Russian Republic in 1961 privately acknowledged that and guessed that perhaps 500,000 in the Soviet Union might eventually become Witnesses if restrictions were lifted. By 1971, there were more than 4500 Witnesses in the Soviet Union.
+
+When the religion was formally recognized in March 1991, Russia reported 15,987 active Jehovah's Witnesses. Beginning in 1993, graduates of [[Watchtower Bible School of Gilead#Gilead School extensions|Gilead Extension School]] in Germany began to be assigned to Russia as missionaries to support the local Witnesses already there. Between 1996 and 2006, Jehovah's Witnesses trained thousands of fulltime ministers in hundreds of [[Pioneer Service School]]s across Russia.<ref>"Russia", ''2008 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', ©2007 Watch Tower, pages 66-255</ref>
+
+Despite local and unofficial harassment, the number of adherents has steadily grown since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. On January 31, 2001, the Russian newspaper ''[[Nezavisimaya Gazeta]]'' said: “Jehovah’s Witnesses occupy fourth place among Russian religions."<ref>As quoted by "Moscow Prosecutor Seeks a Ban on Religious Freedom", ''JW.org Jehovah's Witnesses Official Media Web Site'', [http://www.jw-media.org/rus/20010206.htm As Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref> By 2009, Jehovah's Witnesses reported "an estimated 280,000 Jehovah’s Witnesses and associates in Russia", organized into 2235 congregations.<ref>As quoted by "Moscow judges order retrial", ''JW.org Jehovah's Witnesses Official Media Web Site'', [http://www.jw-media.org/rus/20010531.htm As Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref><ref>"2009 Report of Jehovah's Witnesses Worldwide", ''Watchtower.org'', [http://www.watchtower.org/e/statistics/worldwide_report.htm Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref> Across the former republics of the [[USSR]], over 700,000 attend the meetings of Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>"Russia", ''2008 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', ©2007 Watch Tower, page 176, "700,000 people attend the meetings of Jehovah’s Witnesses all over the territories of the countries of the former Soviet Union"</ref>
+{{seealso|Persecution of Jehovah's Witnesses#Soviet Union|l1=Persecution of Jehovah's Witnesses}}
+
+===Mormons===
+<!---Please do not change section title, which was chosen explicitly to include so-called "Russian Mormonism". --->
+In the [[Novouzensk]] region about 1855, Ivan Grigorev Kanygin founded religious communities with untraditional marriage and communal practices they derived from the [[New Testament]]. Although they called themselves Communists or Methodists (due to a claimed association with [[Methodism]]), an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[priest]] named Khrisanf Rozhdestvenskiy in 1869 labeled them "Mormons" after the contemporaneous American movement, and the term was thereafter applied pejoratively to such adherents. In the 1870s, an unrelated community developed near the [[Volga]] city of [[Samara, Russia|Samara]] which avoided alcohol, tobacco, and swearing, cooperated in commercial enterprises, and governed themselves by "[[apostle]]s" and "[[prophet]]s". Adherents refused to discuss their theological beliefs with outsiders, and it seems that others incorrectly but perhaps sincerely identified them with Mormonism. The "Samara Mormons" came to tolerate the name into the 20th century, though they too had no known connection to the actual [[Latter Day Saint movement]].
+
+[[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] established its first congregation in Russia in 1990, and the Church was recognized in May 1991. By 2010, the Church reported membership of 20,276 in 126 congregations in Russia.<ref>"Country Profiles: Russia", ''LDS.org The Official Church Resource...'', [http://lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/contact-us/russia Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref>
+
 == Bible translation ==
 {{main|Russian Bible Society}}
 The first attempts to translate books of the Bible into modern Russian language of that time took place in 16th and 17th centuries. But the mentioned works (by deacon of Posolsky Prikaz Avraamiy Firsov, pastor E.Gluk, archbishop Methodiy (Smirnov)) were lost during political turbulence and wars.
 
+===Makarios Bible===
+Mikhail Iakovlevich Glukharev, known as [[Archimandrite]] Makarios, was a Russian Orthodox missionary who translated most of the [[Old Testament]] between 1839 and 1847, while a contemporary associate named Gerasim Petrovich Pavsky translated [[Book of Psalms|Psalms]]. Makarios was unable to publish the translation during his lifetime, but a journal called ''Orthodox Review'' acquired and published the ''Makarios Bible'' in installments between 1860 and 1867, under the title ''An Experiment of Translation Into the Russian Language''.
+
+The aging magazines, more than a century old, were discovered in 1993 in the rare-books section of the [[Russian National Library]], and permission was given for the work to be copied and prepared for publication. In January 1997, the ''Religious Organization of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia'' "arranged for nearly 300,000 copies of this Bible to be printed in Italy for distribution throughout Russia and the many other countries where Russian is spoken. In addition to Makarios’ translation of most of the Hebrew Scriptures, this edition of the Bible contains Pavsky’s translation of Psalms as well as the Orthodox Church-authorized synodal translation of the Greek Scriptures."<ref>"A Hidden Treasure Comes to Light", ''The Watchtower'', December 15, 1997, pages 22-27</ref>
+
+===Russian Bible Society===
 The full-scale [[Bible]] translation into Russian language began in 1813 since the establishment of the [[Russian Bible Society]]. The full edition of the Bible with [[Old Testament]] and [[New Testament]] was published in 1876. This work, called also [[Russian Synodal Bible]], is widely used by Protestant communities all over Russia and former USSR countries. Lately appeared several modern translations.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 Russian Bible Society, in Russian]</ref> The [[Russian Bible Society]] since its establishment in 1813 and up to 1826 distributed more than 500 thousand of Bible related books in 41 languages of Russia. Several times in 19-th and 20th centuries activities of the Society were stopped by reactionary policies of the Russian Government.
 
 It was restored in 1990-1991 after a pause connected with the Soviet regime restrictions.<ref>[http://www.biblia.ru/about/history/ History of Russian Bible Society, in Russian]
 </ref>
 
 The opening ceremony of the Building of the Russian Bible Society in Moscow was visited by representatives of [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]], [[Roman Catholic]], and Protestant churches, who joined their efforts in Bible translation and distribution cause. The editions of Society are based on the universal doctrine of the early Christian church and include non-confessional comments. Over 1,000,000 Bible related books are printed per year by that institution. The Bible is also being translated into native languages and dialects of Russia's ethnic groups.
+
+===New World Translation===
+In 2002, the [[Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania]] released ''Holy Bible (with New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures)'' in Russian.<ref>"Announcements", ''Our Kingdom Ministry'', February 2002, page 7</ref> The complete ''[[New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures]]'' in Russian was released in 2007.<ref>"Russia", ''2008 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', ©2007 Watch Tower, page 237</ref> In 2010, ''New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures'' (the New Testament) was released in [[Russian Sign Language]].
+
+The ''New World Translation'' is favored and distributed by [[Jehovah's Witnesses]].
 
 ==See also==
 {{Portal|Christianity}}
llm_output:
Added a section on "Restorationism" and included details about Jehovah's Witnesses and the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Russia.

Not Weaponised. The content appears to provide historical and factual information about religious groups without employing language that could be seen as politically charged or weaponizing cultural narratives.

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

 == Russian Orthodox Church ==
 {{main|Russian Orthodox Church}}
 [[Image:Russia-Sergiev Posad-Trinity Cathedral.jpg|thumb|left|Holy Trinity Cathedral in Sergiev Posad]]
-The Russian Orthodox Church is organized in a hierarchical structure. Every church building and its attendees constitute a [[parish]] (''prikhod''). There are over 27,000 parishes in the Church.
+The Russian Orthodox Church is organized in a hierarchical structure. Every church building and its attendees constitute a [[parish]] (''prikhod''). 
 
 All parishes in a geographical region belong to an [[eparchy]] (''eparkhiya''—equivalent to a Western [[diocese]]). Eparchies are governed by [[bishop]]s (''episkope'' or ''archierey''). There are around 130 Russian Orthodox eparchies worldwide.
 
@@ -22,6 +22,8 @@
 Smaller eparchies are usually governed by a single bishop. Larger eparchies, exarchates, and autonomous churches are governed by [[Metropolitan archbishop|metropolitan]]s and sometimes also have one or more bishops assigned to them.
 
 The highest level of authority in the Church is represented by the [[Patriarch of Moscow and All Russia]], head of the Moscow Patriarchate.
+
+According to figures released on February 2, 2010, Russian Orthodox Church has 160 dioceses including 30,142 parishes served by 207 bishops, 28,434 priests and 3,625 deacons. There are 788 monasteries, including 386 for men and 402 for women.<ref>{{ru icon}}[http://www.patriarchia.ru/db/text/1061651.html Доклад Святейшего Патриарха Кирилла на Архиерейском cовещании 2 февраля 2010 года] patriarchia.ru February 2, 2010</ref>
 
 By information of [[Saint Tikhon's Orthodox University]] and other researchers, from one to several hundred thousands of Orthodox believers were repressed for their faith in the Soviet time.<ref>[http://www.pravmir.ru/skolko-repressirovannyx-v-rossii-postradali-za-xrista/ ''N.E.Emelyanov'', "''How many repressed in Russia suffered for Christ''", ''Pravmir'', ''in Russian'']</ref>

 Conducted in July - August, 2007, bicycle [[missionary]] expedition of Evangelical Christians Baptists faced, by their report,<ref>[http://www.baptist.org.ru/news/english/ Baptist Union News]</ref> serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia. The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President [[Yuri Sipko]], to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to bring them the message of God’s kingdom."
 
 ==Restorationism==
-Certain Christian religions consider themselves to have [[Restorationism (Christian primitivism)|restored primitive Christianity]] and do not consider themselves part of Protestantism. The largest such denominations are [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] and the [[Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]].
+Certain Christian religions consider themselves to have [[Restorationism (Christian primitivism)|restored primitive Christianity]] and do not consider themselves part of Protestantism. The largest such denominations are [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]].
 
 ===Jehovah's Witnesses===
 ''Zion's Watch Tower'' (now called ''[[The Watchtower]]'', the primary journal of the [[Watch Tower Society]] and [[Jehovah's Witnesses]]) had subscribers in Russia as early as 1887, and another Witness publication quoted correspondence from a 1904 group in Russia. Early Russian adherent Semyon Kozlitsky, a Russian Orthodox seminary graduate, associated personally with [[Charles Taze Russell]] as early as 1891 and was an active Jehovah's Witness in Russia, [[Siberia]], and what is now [[Kazakhstan]] until his death in 1935.

 By the opinion of Keston Institute, Protestants are widely present and may well outnumber the Orthodox in some places of [[Siberia]]. There are very few "nominal" believers among them: everywhere they preach, pray and often struggle against local bureaucracy to acquire their rights. Anyway, they are also regarded as respectable, hard-working citizens.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/faith/article684578.ece Timesonline Article]</ref>
 
 Some Protestants (especially at provincial level) report encountering local authorities obstruction of their activities and government restrictions. In April 2007, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] obliged Russian state to pay EUR 10,000 (ten thousand euros) as a non-pecuniary damage for the refusal in registration of the Moscow branch of [[Salvation Army]].

 Certain Christian religions consider themselves to have [[Restorationism (Christian primitivism)|restored primitive Christianity]] and do not consider themselves part of Protestantism. initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

* [[Roman Catholicism in Russia]]
* [[Protestants in Russia]]
* [[Alexander Men]]

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>
