@@ -66,7 +66,7 @@
 Certain Christian religions consider themselves to have [[Restorationism (Christian primitivism)|restored primitive Christianity]] and do not consider themselves part of Protestantism. The largest such denominations are [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]].
 
 ===Jehovah's Witnesses===
-''Zion's Watch Tower'' (now called ''[[The Watchtower]]'', the primary journal of the [[Watch Tower Society]] and [[Jehovah's Witnesses]]) had subscribers in Russia as early as 1887, and another Witness publication quoted correspondence from a 1904 group in Russia. Early Russian adherent Semyon Kozlitsky, a Russian Orthodox seminary graduate, associated personally with [[Charles Taze Russell]] as early as 1891 and was an active Jehovah's Witness in Russia, [[Siberia]], and what is now [[Kazakhstan]] until his death in 1935.
+''Zion's Watch Tower'' (now called ''[[The Watchtower]]'', the primary journal of the [[Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania|Watch Tower Society]] and [[Jehovah's Witnesses]]) had subscribers in Russia as early as 1887, and another Witness publication quoted correspondence from a 1904 group in Russia. Early Russian adherent Semyon Kozlitsky, a Russian Orthodox seminary graduate, associated personally with [[Charles Taze Russell]] as early as 1891 and was an active Jehovah's Witness in Russia, [[Siberia]], and what is now [[Kazakhstan]] until his death in 1935.
 
 In the 1920s, ''The Watch Tower'' began to be published in Russian, and Russian-language congregations were established in the United States and elsewhere. Although there were restrictions in Russia itself, the [[Latvia]] branch translated and printed Russian-language literature and the [[Estonia]] branch broadcast Russian-language radio lectures. In 1935, the Watch Tower Society unsuccessfully attempted to establish a branch office in the [[Soviet Union]] to support the Witnesses already there.
 {{Quote box
@@ -87,7 +87,7 @@
 
 ===Mormons===
 <!---Please do not change section title, which was chosen explicitly to include so-called "Russian Mormonism". --->
-In the [[Novouzensk]] region about 1855, Ivan Grigorev Kanygin founded religious communities with untraditional marriage and communal practices they derived from the [[New Testament]]. Although they called themselves Communists or Methodists (due to a claimed association with [[Methodism]]), an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[priest]] named Khrisanf Rozhdestvenskiy in 1869 labeled them "Mormons" after the contemporaneous American movement, and the term was thereafter applied pejoratively to such adherents. In the 1870s, an unrelated community developed near the [[Volga]] city of [[Samara, Russia|Samara]] which avoided alcohol, tobacco, and swearing, cooperated in commercial enterprises, and governed themselves by "[[apostle]]s" and "[[prophet]]s". Adherents refused to discuss their theological beliefs with outsiders, and it seems that others incorrectly but perhaps sincerely identified them with Mormonism. The "Samara Mormons" came to tolerate the name into the 20th century, though they too had no known connection to the actual [[Latter Day Saint movement]].
+In the [[Novouzensk]] region about 1855, Ivan Grigorev Kanygin founded religious communities with untraditional marriage and communal practices they derived from the [[New Testament]]. Although they called themselves Communists or Methodists (due to a claimed association with [[Methodism]]), an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[priest]] named Khrisanf Rozhdestvenskiy in 1869 labeled them "Mormons" after the contemporaneous American movement, and the term was thereafter applied pejoratively to such adherents. In the 1870s, an unrelated community developed near the [[Volga]] city of [[Samara, Russia|Samara]] which avoided alcohol, tobacco, and swearing, cooperated in commercial enterprises, and governed themselves by "[[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|apostle]]s" and "[[prophet]]s". Adherents refused to discuss their theological beliefs with outsiders, and it seems that others incorrectly but perhaps sincerely identified them with Mormonism. The "Samara Mormons" came to tolerate the name into the 20th century, though they too had no known connection to the actual [[Latter Day Saint movement]].
 
 [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] established its first congregation in Russia in 1990, and the Church was recognized in May 1991. By 2010, the Church reported membership of 20,276 in 126 congregations in Russia.<ref>"Country Profiles: Russia", ''LDS.org The Official Church Resource...'', [http://lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/contact-us/russia Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref>

 {{see also|Persecution of Jehovah's Witnesses#Soviet Union|l1=Persecution of Jehovah's Witnesses}}
 
-===Mormons===
-<!---Please do not change section title, which was chosen explicitly to include so-called "Russian Mormonism". --->
-In the [[Novouzensk]] region about 1855, Ivan Grigorev Kanygin founded religious communities with untraditional marriage and communal practices they derived from the [[New Testament]]. Although they called themselves Communists or Methodists (due to a claimed association with [[Methodism]]), an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[priest]] named Khrisanf Rozhdestvenskiy in 1869 labeled them "Mormons" after the contemporaneous American movement, and the term was thereafter applied pejoratively to such adherents. In the 1870s, an unrelated community developed near the [[Volga]] city of [[Samara, Russia|Samara]] which avoided alcohol, tobacco, and swearing, cooperated in commercial enterprises, and governed themselves by "[[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|apostle]]s" and "[[prophet]]s". Adherents refused to discuss their theological beliefs with outsiders, and it seems that others incorrectly but perhaps sincerely identified them with Mormonism. The "Samara Mormons" came to tolerate the name into the 20th century, though they too had no known connection to the actual [[Latter Day Saint movement]].
+==="Russian Mormons" and Latter-day Saints===
+In the [[Novouzensk]] region about 1855, Ivan Grigorev Kanygin founded religious communities with untraditional marriage and communal practices they derived from the [[New Testament]]. Although they called themselves Communists or Methodists (due to a claimed association with [[Methodism]]), an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[priest]] named Khrisanf Rozhdestvenskiy in 1869 labeled them "Mormons" after the contemporaneous American movement, and the term was thereafter applied pejoratively to such adherents. In the 1870s, an unrelated community developed near the [[Volga]] city of [[Samara, Russia|Samara]] which avoided alcohol, tobacco, and swearing, cooperated in commercial enterprises, and governed themselves by "[[apostle]]s" and "[[prophet]]s". Adherents refused to discuss their theological beliefs with outsiders, and it seems that others incorrectly but perhaps sincerely identified them with [[Latter Day Saint movement|Mormonism]]. The "Samara Mormons" came to tolerate the name into the 20th century, though they too had no known connection to the actual [[Latter Day Saint movement]].{{Cn}}
 
 [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] established its first congregation in Russia in 1990, and the Church was recognized in May 1991. By 2010, the Church reported membership of 20,276 in 126 congregations in Russia.<ref>"Country Profiles: Russia", ''LDS.org The Official Church Resource...'', [http://lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/contact-us/russia Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref>

A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,10 +1,14 @@
 {{Christianity by country}}
-
 '''Christians in Russia''' constitute by some estimates the largest religion of the country (from 15% to 80% of total population by some sources).<ref>''CIA World Factbook''</ref> Approximately 83% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>''US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia, 2006''</ref> By official information, there are 68 eparchies of Russian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate).<ref>''Religion and mass media Institute of Russia site''</ref>
 
 There are from 500,000 to one million so-called [[Old Believers]], who represent an older form of [[Russian Orthodox]] Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms. According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name="USgov"/> In Russia today, about 280,000 associate with over 2200 congregations of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] reports over 20,000 adherents in 126 congregations.
 
 The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.<ref name="USgov"/> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.com/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings. 
+
+==Demographics==
+The ancestors of many of today’s Russians adopted Orthodox Christianity in the 10th century.<ref name=encarta>{{cite web|last=Microsoft Encarta Online Encyclopedia 2007|title=Russia|url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761569000_6/Russia.html|accessdate =2007-12-27}}</ref> According to the [[U.S. Department of State]], approximately 100 million citizens consider themselves Russian Orthodox Christians, amounting to 70% of population, although only 5 percent of Russians call themselves observant.<ref>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2010/148977.htm Russia], [[U.S. Department of State]]</ref> However the Church claims a membership of 80 million.<ref name="Page">{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article551693.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=The rise of Russian Muslims worries Orthodox Church | first=Jeremy | last=Page | date=2005-08-05 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> According to a poll{{Which?|date=February 2011}} by the [[VCIOM|Russian Public Opinion Research Center]], 63% of respondents considered themselves Russian Orthodox.<ref name=religionsurvey>{{cite web|title={{ru icon}}Опубликована подробная сравнительная статистика религиозности в России и Польше|publisher=religare.ru|date=6 June 2007|url=http://www.religare.ru/article42432.htm|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref>
+
+There are missionary works carying out among immigrants from ex-Soviet republics, many of them Muslims; and recently, large numbers of Muslims - among them Tatars, Uzbeks, Chechens and Dagestanis - are converting to Christianity.<ref>[http://www.orthodoxytoday.org/blog/2009/11/orthodox-priest-who-converted-muslims-murdered-in-russia/ Orthodox Priest Who Converted Muslims Murdered in Russia]</ref>
 
 == Russian Orthodox Church ==
 {{main|Russian Orthodox Church}}
llm_output:

 The Russian Orthodox Church is organized in a hierarchical structure. Every church building and its attendees constitute a [[parish]] (''prikhod'').

Between 1996 and 2006, Jehovah's Witnesses trained thousands of full-time ministers in hundreds of [[Pioneer Service School]]s across Russia.<ref>"Russia", ''2008 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', ©2007 Watch Tower, pages 66-255</ref>
 
 Despite local and unofficial harassment, the number of adherents has steadily grown since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. On January 31, 2001, the Russian newspaper ''[[Nezavisimaya Gazeta]]'' said: “Jehovah’s Witnesses occupy fourth place among Russian religions."<ref>As quoted by "Moscow Prosecutor Seeks a Ban on Religious Freedom", ''JW.org Jehovah's Witnesses Official Media Web Site'', [http://www.jw-media.org/rus/20010206.htm As Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref> By 2009, Jehovah's Witnesses reported "an estimated 280,000 Jehovah’s Witnesses and associates in Russia", organized into 2235 congregations.<ref>As quoted by "Moscow judges order retrial", ''JW.org Jehovah's Witnesses Official Media Web Site'', [http://www.jw-media.org/rus/20010531.htm As Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref><ref>"2009 Report of Jehovah's Witnesses Worldwide", ''Watchtower.org'', [http://www.watchtower.org/e/statistics/worldwide_report.htm Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref> Across the former republics of the [[USSR]], over 700,000 attend the meetings of Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>"Russia", ''2008 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', ©2007 Watch Tower, page 176, "700,000 people attend the meetings of Jehovah’s Witnesses all over the territories of the countries of the former Soviet Union"</ref>

 ==="Russian Mormons" and Latter-day Saints===
-In the [[Novouzensk]] region about 1855, Ivan Grigorev Kanygin founded religious communities with untraditional marriage and communal practices they derived from the [[New Testament]]. Although they called themselves Communists or Methodists (due to a claimed association with [[Methodism]]), an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[priest]] named Khrisanf Rozhdestvenskiy in 1869 labeled them "Mormons" after the contemporaneous American movement, and the term was thereafter applied pejoratively to such adherents. In the 1870s, an unrelated community developed near the [[Volga]] city of [[Samara, Russia|Samara]] which avoided alcohol, tobacco, and swearing, cooperated in commercial enterprises, and governed themselves by "[[apostle]]s" and "[[prophet]]s". Adherents refused to discuss their theological beliefs with outsiders, and it seems that others incorrectly but perhaps sincerely identified them with [[Latter Day Saint movement|Mormonism]]. The "Samara Mormons" came to tolerate the name into the 20th century, though they too had no known connection to the actual [[Latter Day Saint movement]].{{Cn|date=August 2012}}
+In the [[Novouzensk]] region about 1855, Ivan Grigorev Kanygin founded religious communities with untraditional marriage and communal practices they derived from the [[New Testament]]. Although they called themselves Communists or Methodists (due to a claimed association with [[Methodism]]), an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[priest]] named Khrisanf Rozhdestvenskiy in 1869 labeled them "Mormons" after the contemporaneous American movement, and the term was thereafter applied pejoratively to such adherents. In the 1870s, an unrelated community developed near the [[Volga]] city of [[Samara, Russia|Samara]] which avoided alcohol, tobacco, and swearing, cooperated in commercial enterprises, and governed themselves by "[[apostle]]s" and "[[prophet]]s". Adherents refused to discuss their theological beliefs with outsiders, and it seems that others incorrectly but perhaps sincerely identified them with [[Latter Day Saint movement|Mormonism]]. The "Samara Mormons" came to tolerate the name into the 20th century, though they too had no known connection to the actual [[Latter Day Saint movement]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2012}}
 
 [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] established its first congregation in Russia in 1990, and the Church was recognized in May 1991. By 2010, the Church reported membership of 20,276 in 126 congregations in Russia.<ref>"Country Profiles: Russia", ''LDS.org The Official Church Resource...'', [http://lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/contact-us/russia Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref>

 ===Jehovah's Witnesses===
 ''Zion's Watch Tower'' (now called ''[[The Watchtower]]'', the primary journal of the [[Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania|Watch Tower Society]] and [[Jehovah's Witnesses]]) had subscribers in Russia as early as 1887, and another Witness publication quoted correspondence from a 1904 group in Russia. Early Russian adherent Semyon Kozlitsky, a Russian Orthodox seminary graduate, associated personally with [[Charles Taze Russell]] as early as 1891 and was an active Jehovah's Witness in Russia, [[Siberia]], and what is now [[Kazakhstan]] until his death in 1935.

-The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.<ref name="USgov"/> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.com/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings.
+The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates;<ref name="USgov"/> meanwhile, a Russian government survey determined that there are only about 140,000.<ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg</ref><ref>http://sreda.org/arena</ref> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.com/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings.
 
 ==Demographics==
 The ancestors of many of today’s Russians adopted Orthodox Christianity in the 10th century.<ref name=encarta>{{cite web|last=Microsoft Encarta Online Encyclopedia 2007|title=Russia|url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761569000_6/Russia.html|accessdate =2007-12-27}}</ref> According to the [[U.S. Department of State]], approximately 100 million citizens consider themselves Russian Orthodox Christians, amounting to 70% of population, although only 5 percent of Russians call themselves observant.<ref>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2010/148977.htm Russia], [[U.S. Department of State]]</ref> However the Church claims a membership of 80 million.<ref name="Page">{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article551693.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=The rise of Russian Muslims worries Orthodox Church | first=Jeremy | last=Page | date=2005-08-05 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> According to a poll{{Which|date=February 2011}} by the [[VCIOM|Russian Public Opinion Research Center]], 63% of respondents considered themselves Russian Orthodox.<ref name=religionsurvey>{{cite web|title={{ru icon}}Опубликована подробная сравнительная статистика религиозности в России и Польше|publisher=religare.ru|date=6 June 2007|url=http://www.religare.ru/article42432.htm|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref>

[[Pope John Paul II]] for years expressed a desire to visit Russia, but the Russian Orthodox Church has for years resisted.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia   | date= July 3, 2006| title= Putin warns of 'clash of civilisations' at Moscow religious summit  | format= | work= Ecumenical News International | url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> 
 In April 2002, Bishop Jerry Mazur of Eastern Siberia was striped of his visa, forcing the appointment of a new bishop for that diocese.<ref>{{cite web | author=Myers, Steven Lee  | date= July 9, 2002| title= Church Dispute Festers | format= | work= New York Times| url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> In 2002, five foreign Catholic priests were denied visas to return to Russia, construction of a new cathedral was blocked in [[Pskov]], and a church in southern Russia was shot at.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia | date= September 13, 2002| title= Archbishop Appeals To Rights Groups  | format= | work= New York Times | url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> On Christmas Day 2005, Russian Orthodox activists planned to picket outside of Moscow's Catholic Cathedral, but the picket was cancelled. Despite the recent thawing of relations with the election of [[Pope Benedict XVI]], there are still issues such as the readiness of the police to protect Catholics and other minorities from persecution.<ref>{{cite web | author=  | date= June 7, 2006| title=Whose side are police on? Russian Christians ask | format= | work= Catholic World News | url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
 
-One thousand Russian Catholics gathered in the Virgin Mary’s Immaculate Conception Cathedral in Moscow to watch the [[Pope John Paul II|Pope's]] funeral in 2005. Earlier [[Pope John Paul II]] gave an 18th century copy of the famous [[Our Lady of Kazan]] icon to the Russian Orthodox Church.

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

-In the 1950s and 1960s, Jehovah's Witnesses were surveiled, infiltrated, harassed, and persecuted by the Soviet government, which seems to have taken decades to conclude that the faith was not a threat. By 1971, there were more than 4500 Witnesses in the Soviet Union.

+The number of adherents has steadily grown since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. On January 31, 2001, the Russian newspaper ''[[Nezavisimaya Gazeta]]'' said: "Jehovah's Witnesses occupy fourth place among Russian religions."<ref>As quoted by "Moscow Prosecutor Seeks a Ban on Religious Freedom", ''JW.org Jehovah's Witnesses Official Media Web Site'', [http://www.jw-media.org/rus/20010206.htm As Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref> By 2009, Jehovah's Witnesses reported "an estimated 280,000 Jehovah's Witnesses and associates in Russia".<ref>As quoted by "Moscow judges order retrial", ''JW.org Jehovah's Witnesses Official Media Web Site'', [http://www.jw-media.org/rus/20010531.htm As Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref><ref>"2009 Report of Jehovah's Witnesses Worldwide", ''Watchtower.org'', [http://www.watchtower.org/e/statistics/worldwide_report.htm Retrieved 2010-08-04]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>''US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia, 2006''</ref> In Russia today, about 280,000 associate with over 2200 congregations of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] reports over 20,000 adherents in 126 congregations.
 
 The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates;<ref name="USgov"/> meanwhile, a Russian government survey determined that there are only about 140,000.<ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg</ref><ref>http://sreda.org/arena</ref> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings.
 
-According to a global survey conducted at the end of 2013, 71% of surveyed [[Russians]] identify themselves as [[Christian]]; of these, 69% identify as either [[Russian Orthodoxy|Russian]] or [[Eastern Orthodox]], and 2% as [[Protestantism in Russia|Protestants]] or another branch of Christianity.<ref>[http://www.wingia.com/web/files/news/126/file/126.pdf 2013 End of the Year Survey - Russia] ''[[WIN/GIA]]''</ref>
+According to a 2012 Sreda Arena survey 46.6% of the Russian population is Christian, including 41% Russian Orthodox.<ref name="sreda.org">[http://sreda.org/arena Arena - Atlas of Religions and Nationalities in Russia]. 2012 National Survey of Religions in Russia. Sreda.org</ref>
+
+There is no official census of religion in Russia, and estimates are based on surveys only. In August 2012, [http://sreda.org/arena ARENA] determined that about 46.8% of Russians are Christians (including Orthodox, Catholic, Protestant, and non-denominational), which is slightly less than an absolute 50%+ majority. However, later that year the musulman Levada Center determined that 76% of Russians are Christians,<ref>http://www.levada.ru/17-12-2012/v-rossii-74-pravoslavnykh-i-7-musulman Levada Center</ref> and in June 2013 the Public Opinion Foundation<ref>http://fom.ru/obshchestvo/10953 Public Opinion Foundation</ref> determined that 65% of Russians are Christians. These findings are in line with Pew's 2011 survey,<ref>http://www.pewforum.org/2011/12/19/global-christianity-exec/ Pew</ref> which determined that 73.6% of Russians are Christians, with VTSIOM's 2010 survey (~77% Christian),<ref>http://wciom.ru/index.php?id=268&uid=13365 VTSIOM</ref> and with Ipsos MORI's 2011 survey (69%).<ref>http://www.fgi-tbff.org/sites/default/files/elfinder/FGIImages/Research/fromresearchtopolicy/ipsos_mori_briefing_pack.pdf#page=40 Ipsos MORI</ref> 
 
 ==Demographics==
-The ancestors of many of today’s Russians adopted Orthodox Christianity in the 10th century.<ref name=encarta>{{cite web|last=Microsoft Encarta Online Encyclopedia 2007|title=Russia|url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761569000_6/Russia.html|accessdate =2007-12-27}}</ref> According to the [[U.S. Department of State]], approximately 100 million citizens consider themselves Russian Orthodox Christians, amounting to 70% of population, although only 5 percent of Russians call themselves observant.<ref>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2010/148977.htm Russia], [[U.S. Department of State]]</ref> However the Church claims a membership of 80 million.<ref name="Page">{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article551693.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=The rise of Russian Muslims worries Orthodox Church | first=Jeremy | last=Page | date=2005-08-05 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> According to a poll{{Which|date=February 2011}} by the [[VCIOM|Russian Public Opinion Research Center]], 63% of respondents considered themselves Russian Orthodox.<ref name=religionsurvey>{{cite web|title=Опубликована подробная сравнительная статистика религиозности в России и Польше|language=Russian |publisher=religare.ru|date=6 June 2007|url=http://www.religare.ru/article42432.htm|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref>
+{{Pie chart
+|thumb = right
+|caption = Makeup of Russia's Christianity
+|label1 = [[Russian Orthodox Church|Russian Orthodox Christians]]
+|value1 = 87
+|color1 = DarkOrchid
+|label2 = [[Christian]]s not belonging to any denomination

+|value5 = 0.4

+|value6 = 0.2
+|color6 = Yellow

+According to a survey held in Russia by Sreda Arena, and published in 2012, 66,840,000 people in the country (46.6% of the total population of that time, of 142,800,000) identify as Christians.<ref name="sreda.org"/>
 
-
+This includes:<ref name="sreda.org"/>
+* 41% — 58,800,000 members of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]];
+* 4% — 5,900,000 people identifying as [[Christian]]s without belonging to any church
+* 1.5% — 2,100,000 people believing in [[Orthodox Christianity]] without belonging to any Orthodox church or belonging to non-Russian churches
+* 0.2% — 400,000 [[Old Believers]]
+* 0.2% — 300,000 [[Protestantism|Protestants]]
+* 0.1% — 140,000 members of the [[Catholic Church]]

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

 {{Christianity by country}}
-'''Christians in Russia''' constitute by some estimates the largest religion of the country (from 15% to 80% of total population by some sources).<ref>''CIA World Factbook''</ref> Approximately 83% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>''US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia, 2006''</ref> By official information, there are 68 eparchies of Russian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate).<ref>''Religion and mass media Institute of Russia site''</ref>
+'''Christians in Russia''' constitute by some estimates the largest religion of the country, with nearly 50% of the population identifying as [[Christian]]. The largest tradition is the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. By official information, there are 68 eparchies of Russian Orthodox Church.<ref>''Religion and mass media Institute of Russia site''</ref>
 
-There are from 500,000 to one million so-called [[Old Believers]], who represent an older form of [[Russian Orthodox]] Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms. According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name="USgov"/> In Russia today, about 280,000 associate with over 2200 congregations of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] reports over 20,000 adherents in 126 congregations.
+There are from 500,000 to one million so-called [[Old Believers]], who represent an older form of Russian Orthodox Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms. According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>''US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia, 2006''</ref> In Russia today, about 280,000 associate with over 2200 congregations of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] reports over 20,000 adherents in 126 congregations.
 
 The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates;<ref name="USgov"/> meanwhile, a Russian government survey determined that there are only about 140,000.<ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg</ref><ref>http://sreda.org/arena</ref> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings.
 
-According to a global survey conducted at the end of 2013, 71% of surveyed [[Russians]] identify themselves as [[Christian]]; of these, 69% identify as either [[Russian Orthodoxy|Russian]] or [[Eastern Orthodox]], and 2% as [[Protestantism in Russia|Protestants]] or another branch of Christianity.<ref>[http://www.wingia.com/web/files/news/126/file/126.pdf 2013 End of the Year Survey - Russia] ''[[WIN/GIA]]''</ref>
+According to a 2012 Sreda Arena survey 46.6% of the Russian population is Christian, including 41% Russian Orthodox.<ref name="sreda.org">[http://sreda.org/arena Arena - Atlas of Religions and Nationalities in Russia]. 2012 National Survey of Religions in Russia. Sreda.org</ref>
+
+There is no official census of religion in Russia, and estimates are based on surveys only. In August 2012, [http://sreda.org/arena ARENA] determined that about 46.8% of Russians are Christians (including Orthodox, Catholic, Protestant, and non-denominational), which is slightly less than an absolute 50%+ majority. However, later that year the musulman Levada Center determined that 76% of Russians are Christians,<ref>http://www.levada.ru/17-12-2012/v-rossii-74-pravoslavnykh-i-7-musulman Levada Center</ref> and in June 2013 the Public Opinion Foundation<ref>http://fom.ru/obshchestvo/10953 Public Opinion Foundation</ref> determined that 65% of Russians are Christians. These findings are in line with Pew's 2011 survey,<ref>http://www.pewforum.org/2011/12/19/global-christianity-exec/ Pew</ref> which determined that 73.6% of Russians are Christians, with VTSIOM's 2010 survey (~77% Christian),<ref>http://wciom.ru/index.php?id=268&uid=13365 VTSIOM</ref> and with Ipsos MORI's 2011 survey (69%).<ref>http://www.fgi-tbff.org/sites/default/files/elfinder/FGIImages/Research/fromresearchtopolicy/ipsos_mori_briefing_pack.pdf#page=40 Ipsos MORI</ref> 
 
 ==Demographics==
-The ancestors of many of today’s Russians adopted Orthodox Christianity in the 10th century.<ref name=encarta>{{cite web|last=Microsoft Encarta Online Encyclopedia 2007|title=Russia|url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761569000_6/Russia.html|accessdate =2007-12-27}}</ref> According to the [[U.S. Department of State]], approximately 100 million citizens consider themselves Russian Orthodox Christians, amounting to 70% of population, although only 5 percent of Russians call themselves observant.<ref>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2010/148977.htm Russia], [[U.S. Department of State]]</ref> However the Church claims a membership of 80 million.<ref name="Page">{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article551693.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=The rise of Russian Muslims worries Orthodox Church | first=Jeremy | last=Page | date=2005-08-05 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> According to a poll{{Which|date=February 2011}} by the [[VCIOM|Russian Public Opinion Research Center]], 63% of respondents considered themselves Russian Orthodox.<ref name=religionsurvey>{{cite web|title=Опубликована подробная сравнительная статистика религиозности в России и Польше|language=Russian |publisher=religare.ru|date=6 June 2007|url=http://www.religare.ru/article42432.htm|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref>
+{{Pie chart
+|thumb = right
+|caption = Makeup of Russia's Christianity
+|label1 = [[Russian Orthodox Church|Russian Orthodox Christians]]
+|value1 = 87
+|color1 = DarkOrchid
+|label2 = [[Christian]]s not belonging to any denomination
+|value2 = 8.8
+|color2 = Turquoise
+|label3 = Other type of [[Orthodox Christians]]
+|value3 = 3
+|color3 = MediumOrchid
+|label4 = [[Old Believers]]
+|value4 = 0.5
+|color4 = Violet
+|label5 = [[Protestantism|Protestants]]
+|value5 = 0.4
+|color5 = DodgerBlue
+|label6 = [[Catholic Church|Catholics]]
+|value6 = 0.2
+|color6 = Yellow
+}}
+According to a survey held in Russia by Sreda Arena, and published in 2012, 66,840,000 people in the country (46.6% of the total population of that time, of 142,800,000) identify as Christians.<ref name="sreda.org"/>
 
-
+This includes:<ref name="sreda.org"/>
+* 41% — 58,800,000 members of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]];
+* 4% — 5,900,000 people identifying as [[Christian]]s without belonging to any church
+* 1.5% — 2,100,000 people believing in [[Orthodox Christianity]] without belonging to any Orthodox church or belonging to non-Russian churches
+* 0.2% — 400,000 [[Old Believers]]
+* 0.2% — 300,000 [[Protestantism|Protestants]]
+* 0.1% — 140,000 members of the [[Catholic Church]]
 
 == Russian Orthodox Church ==
 {{main|Russian Orthodox Church}}

A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>''US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia, 2006''</ref> In Russia today, about 280,000 associate with over 2200 congregations of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] reports over 20,000 adherents in 126 congregations.
 
 The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates;<ref name="USgov"/> meanwhile, a Russian government survey determined that there are only about 140,000.<ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg</ref><ref>http://sreda.org/arena</ref> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings.

 By 1939, thousands of Jehovah's Witnesses were already residing in the [[Baltic states]] when the Soviet Union absorbed those formerly independent countries. In the 1940s, the Soviet government forcibly dispersed thousands of Witnesses in a program named [[Operation North]], later described by Dr. N. S. Gordienko, a professor at [[Herzen University]] as having had "just the opposite of what was expected; they wanted to weaken the organization of Jehovah’s Witnesses in the USSR, but in fact they only strengthened it". In the 1950s and 1960s, Jehovah's Witnesses were tracked, infiltrated, harassed, and persecuted by the Soviet government. By 1971, there were more than 4500 Witnesses in the Soviet Union.

-

Beginning in 1993, graduates of [[Watchtower Bible School of Gilead#Gilead School extensions|Gilead Extension School]] in Germany began to be assigned to Russia as missionaries to support the local Witnesses already there. Between 1996 and 2006, Jehovah's Witnesses trained thousands of full-time ministers in Russia.<ref>"Russia", ''2008 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses'', ©2007 Watch Tower, pages 66-255</ref> The number of adherents has steadily grown since the dissolution of the Soviet Union.  The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates;<ref name="USgov"/> meanwhile, a Russian government survey determined that there are only about 140,000.<ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg</ref><ref>http://sreda.org/arena</ref> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings.
 
-According to a 2012 Sreda Arena survey 46.6% of the Russian population is Christian, including 41% Russian Orthodox.<ref name="sreda.org">[http://sreda.org/arena Arena - Atlas of Religions and Nationalities in Russia]. 2012 National Survey of Religions in Russia. Sreda.org</ref>

However, later that year the musulman Levada Center determined that 76% of Russians are Christians,<ref>http://www.levada.ru/17-12-2012/v-rossii-74-pravoslavnykh-i-7-musulman Levada Center</ref> and in June 2013 the Public Opinion Foundation<ref>http://fom.ru/obshchestvo/10953 Public Opinion Foundation</ref> determined that 65% of Russians are Christians. These findings are in line with Pew's 2011 survey,<ref>http://www.pewforum.org/2011/12/19/global-christianity-exec/ Pew</ref> which determined that 73.6% of Russians are Christians, with VTSIOM's 2010 survey (~77% Christian),<ref>http://wciom.ru/index.php?id=268&uid=13365 VTSIOM</ref> and with Ipsos MORI's 2011 survey (69%).<ref>http://www.fgi-tbff.org/sites/default/files/elfinder/FGIImages/Research/fromresearchtopolicy/ipsos_mori_briefing_pack.pdf#page=40 Ipsos MORI</ref>

{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

+There are from 500,000 to one million so-called [[Old Believers]], who represent an older form of [[Russian Orthodox]] Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms. According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name="USgov"/> In Russia today, about 280,000 associate with over 2200 congregations of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] reports over 20,000 adherents in 126 congregations.
 
 The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates;<ref name="USgov"/> meanwhile, a Russian government survey determined that there are only about 140,000.<ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg</ref><ref>http://sreda.org/arena</ref> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings.
 
-According to a 2012 Sreda Arena survey 46.6% of the Russian population is Christian, including 41% Russian Orthodox.<ref name="sreda.org">[http://sreda.org/arena Arena - Atlas of Religions and Nationalities in Russia]. 2012 National Survey of Religions in Russia. Sreda.org</ref>
-
-There is no official census of religion in Russia, and estimates are based on surveys only. In August 2012, [http://sreda.org/arena ARENA] determined that about 46.8% of Russians are Christians (including Orthodox, Catholic, Protestant, and non-denominational), which is slightly less than an absolute 50%+ majority. However, later that year the musulman Levada Center determined that 76% of Russians are Christians,<ref>http://www.levada.ru/17-12-2012/v-rossii-74-pravoslavnykh-i-7-musulman Levada Center</ref> and in June 2013 the Public Opinion Foundation<ref>http://fom.ru/obshchestvo/10953 Public Opinion Foundation</ref> determined that 65% of Russians are Christians. These findings are in line with Pew's 2011 survey,<ref>http://www.pewforum.org/2011/12/19/global-christianity-exec/ Pew</ref> which determined that 73.6% of Russians are Christians, with VTSIOM's 2010 survey (~77% Christian),<ref>http://wciom.ru/index.php?id=268&uid=13365 VTSIOM</ref> and with Ipsos MORI's 2011 survey (69%).<ref>http://www.fgi-tbff.org/sites/default/files/elfinder/FGIImages/Research/fromresearchtopolicy/ipsos_mori_briefing_pack.pdf#page=40 Ipsos MORI</ref> 
+According to a global survey conducted at the end of 2013, 71% of surveyed [[Russians]] identify themselves as [[Christian]]; of these, 69% identify as either [[Russian Orthodoxy|Russian]] or [[Eastern Orthodox]], and 2% as [[Protestantism in Russia|Protestants]] or another branch of Christianity.<ref>[http://www.wingia.com/web/files/news/126/file/126.pdf 2013 End of the Year Survey - Russia] ''[[WIN/GIA]]''</ref>

-According to a survey held in Russia by Sreda Arena, and published in 2012, 66,840,000 people in the country (46.6% of the total population of that time, of 142,800,000) identify as Christians.<ref name="sreda.org"/>
+The ancestors of many of today’s Russians adopted Orthodox Christianity in the 10th century.<ref name=encarta>{{cite web|last=Microsoft Encarta Online Encyclopedia 2007|title=Russia|url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761569000_6/Russia.html|accessdate =2007-12-27}}</ref> According to the [[U.S. Department of State]], approximately 100 million citizens consider themselves Russian Orthodox Christians, amounting to 70% of population, although only 5 percent of Russians call themselves observant.<ref>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2010/148977.htm Russia], [[U.S. Department of State]]</ref> However the Church claims a membership of 80 million.<ref name="Page">{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article551693.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=The rise of Russian Muslims worries Orthodox Church | first=Jeremy | last=Page | date=2005-08-05 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> According to a poll{{Which|date=February 2011}} by the [[VCIOM|Russian Public Opinion Research Center]], 63% of respondents considered themselves Russian Orthodox.<ref name=religionsurvey>{{cite web|title=Опубликована подробная сравнительная статистика религиозности в России и Польше|language=Russian |publisher=religare.ru|date=6 June 2007|url=http://www.religare.ru/article42432.htm|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref>
 
-This includes:<ref name="sreda.org"/>
-* 41% — 58,800,000 members of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]];
-* 4% — 5,900,000 people identifying as [[Christian]]s without belonging to any church
-* 1.5% — 2,100,000 people believing in [[Orthodox Christianity]] without belonging to any Orthodox church or belonging to non-Russian churches
-* 0.2% — 400,000 [[Old Believers]]
-* 0.2% — 300,000 [[Protestantism|Protestants]]
-* 0.1% — 140,000 members of the [[Catholic Church]]
+

 By the opinion of Keston Institute, Protestants are widely present and may well outnumber the Orthodox in some places of [[Siberia]]. There are very few "nominal" believers among them: everywhere they preach, pray and often struggle against local bureaucracy to acquire their rights. They are also regarded as respectable, hard-working citizens.<ref>''The religious maelstrom of modern Russia, Timesonline, July 2008''</ref>
 
+
+However most Russian people accuse the prodestant churches of trying to convert the entire country, because of this numerous occasions where Protestants have been attacked and missionaries murdered, one case was when two missionaries were kidnapped and held hostage in Moscow for three days, another occasion includes when a pastor in Krasnoyarsk was murdered by a woman after a service, and more recently three churches was burned to the ground in Siberia.
+
+
 Some Protestants, especially at provincial level, report encountering local authorities obstruction of their activities and government restrictions. In April 2007, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] obliged Russian state to pay EUR 10,000 (ten thousand euros) as a non-pecuniary damage for the refusal in registration of the Moscow branch of [[Salvation Army]].
 
 Conducted in July - August, 2007, bicycle [[missionary]] expedition of Evangelical Christians Baptists faced, by their report,<ref>''Baptist Union of Russia site, News''</ref> serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia. The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above-mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President [[Yuri Sipko]], to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to bring them the message of God’s kingdom."

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

@@ -96,7 +96,7 @@
 
 Some Protestants, especially at provincial level, report encountering local authorities obstruction of their activities and government restrictions. In April 2007, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] obliged Russian state to pay EUR 10,000 (ten thousand euros) as a non-pecuniary damage for the refusal in registration of the Moscow branch of [[Salvation Army]].
 
-Conducted in July - August, 2007, bicycle [[missionary]] expedition of Evangelical Christians Baptists faced, by their report,<ref>''Baptist Union of Russia site, News''</ref> serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia. The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above-mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President [[Yuri Sipko]], to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to bring them the message of God’s kingdom."
+Conducted in July - August, 2007, bicycle [[missionary]] expedition of Evangelical Christians Baptists faced, by their report,<ref>''Baptist Union of Russia site, News''</ref> serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia. The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above-mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President [[Yuri Sipko]], to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to convert them."
 
 ==Restorationism==
 Certain Christian religions consider themselves to have [[Restorationism (Christian primitivism)|restored primitive Christianity]] and do not consider themselves part of Protestantism.  Many mainstream Christians likewise do not consider them part of Protestantism or even Christianity,  but a cult <ref>http://carm.org/terminology-mormons-and-jehovahs-witnesses</ref>   The largest such denominations are [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]].
llm_output:

Not Weaponised. The change reflects a shift in language that emphasizes the intent of the missionary work but does not invoke any specific cultural heritage narratives or weaponization terms associated with the ongoing geopolitical conflicts.

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

 There is no official census of religion in Russia, and estimates are based on surveys only. According to a 2012 Sreda Arena survey 46.6% of the Russian population is Christian, including 41% Russian Orthodox.<ref name="sreda.org">[http://sreda.org/arena Arena - Atlas of Religions and Nationalities in Russia]. 2012 National Survey of Religions in Russia.  The Catholic Archbishop of Moscow has voiced his support for religious education in state sponsored schools, citing the examples of other countries.<ref>{{cite web | author= | date= June 19, 2006| title= Russian Catholics back religious education at school  | work= Russian News and Information Agency | url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
 
 Relations with the Russian Orthodox church have been rocky for nearly a millennium, and attempts at re-establishing Catholicism have met with opposition. [[Pope John Paul II]] for years expressed a desire to visit Russia, but the Russian Orthodox Church has for years resisted.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia   | date= July 3, 2006| title= Putin warns of 'clash of civilisations' at Moscow religious summit  | format= | work= Ecumenical News International | url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> 
-In April 2002, Bishop Jerry Mazur of Eastern Siberia was striped of his visa, forcing the appointment of a new bishop for that diocese.<ref>{{cite web | author=Myers, Steven Lee  | date= July 9, 2002| title= Church Dispute Festers | format= | work= New York Times| url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> In 2002, five foreign Catholic priests were denied visas to return to Russia, construction of a new cathedral was blocked in [[Pskov]], and a church in southern Russia was shot at.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia | date= September 13, 2002| title= Archbishop Appeals To Rights Groups  | format= | work= New York Times | url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> On Christmas Day 2005, Russian Orthodox activists planned to picket outside of Moscow's Catholic Cathedral, but the picket was cancelled. Despite the recent thawing of relations with the election of [[Pope Benedict XVI]], there are still issues such as the readiness of the police to protect Catholics and other minorities from persecution.<ref>{{cite web | author=  | date= June 7, 2006| title=Whose side are police on? Russian Christians ask | format= | work= Catholic World News | url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
+In April 2002, Bishop Jerry Mazur of Eastern Siberia was stripped of his visa, forcing the appointment of a new bishop for that diocese.<ref>{{cite web | author=Myers, Steven Lee  | date= July 9, 2002| title= Church Dispute Festers | format= | work= New York Times| url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> In 2002, five foreign Catholic priests were denied visas to return to Russia, construction of a new cathedral was blocked in [[Pskov]], and a church in southern Russia was shot at.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia | date= September 13, 2002| title= Archbishop Appeals To Rights Groups  | format= | work= New York Times | url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref> On Christmas Day 2005, Russian Orthodox activists planned to picket outside of Moscow's Catholic Cathedral, but the picket was cancelled. Despite the recent thawing of relations with the election of [[Pope Benedict XVI]], there are still issues such as the readiness of the police to protect Catholics and other minorities from persecution.<ref>{{cite web | author=  | date= June 7, 2006| title=Whose side are police on? Russian Christians ask | format= | work= Catholic World News | url= | accessdate=2006-07-04}}</ref>
 
 One thousand Russian Catholics gathered in the Virgin Mary’s Immaculate Conception Cathedral in Moscow to watch the [[Pope John Paul II|Pope's]] funeral in 2005. Earlier [[Pope John Paul II]] gave an 18th-century copy of the famous [[Our Lady of Kazan]] icon to the Russian Orthodox Church.

-In June 2016, Russia passed an anti-terrorism law that bans proselytizing and missionary activities. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2016/july/russia-ban-evangelism-effect.html |title=Russia Bans on Evangelism is Now in Effect}}</ref> On July 8, 2016 the [[U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom]] (USCIRF) strongly condemned these measures stating, "Under the guise of confronting terrorism, they would grant authorities sweeping powers to curtail civil liberties, including setting broad restrictions on religious practices that would make it very difficult for religious groups to operate." <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/news-room/press-releases/russia-uscirf-condemns-enactment-anti-terrorism-laws |title= RUSSIA: USCIRF Condemns Enactment of Anti-Terrorism Laws}}</ref> That year the USCIRF placed Russia on its Tier 2 list. An article in [[the Christian Post]] discussing the ban on proselytizing stated, "Human rights and religious freedom advocates argue that the law 'doesn't do that much to defend from terrorism and only prevents Christians and others who are not Orthodox from preaching and proselytizing.'" <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/russian-man-caught-playing-pokemon-church-sentenced-prison-inciting-religious-hatred-182084/#kSt8i6FslPGE4Tew.99 |title=Russian Man Caught Playing Pokemon in Church Could be Sentenced to Prison for 'Inciting Religious Hatred'}}</ref> In 2017, the USCIRF reclassified Russia, as a Tier 1 country thus one of the world's worst violators of religious liberty, recommending that the U.S. government deem Russia a "country of particular concern" under the International Religious Freedom Act. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/sites/default/files/Russia.2017.pdf|title=RUSSIA TIER1 USCIRF RECOMMENDED COUNTRIES OF PARTICULAR CONCERN (CPC)|date=April 26, 2017}}</ref>
+In June 2016, Russia passed an anti-terrorism law that bans proselytizing and missionary activities. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2016/july/russia-ban-evangelism-effect.html |title=Russia Bans on Evangelism is Now in Effect}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/vladimir-putin-russia-foreign-religion-crackdown-498551|title=A NEW RUSSIAN LAW TARGETS EVANGELICALS AND OTHER ‘FOREIGN’ RELIGIONS}}</ref> July 8, 2016 the [[U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom]] (USCIRF) strongly condemned these measures stating, "Under the guise of confronting terrorism, they would grant authorities sweeping powers to curtail civil liberties, including setting broad restrictions on religious practices that would make it very difficult for religious groups to operate." <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/news-room/press-releases/russia-uscirf-condemns-enactment-anti-terrorism-laws |title= RUSSIA: USCIRF Condemns Enactment of Anti-Terrorism Laws}}</ref> That year the USCIRF placed Russia on its Tier 2 list. An article in [[the Christian Post]] discussing the ban on proselytizing stated, "Human rights and religious freedom advocates argue that the law 'doesn't do that much to defend from terrorism and only prevents Christians and others who are not Orthodox from preaching and proselytizing.'" <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/russian-man-caught-playing-pokemon-church-sentenced-prison-inciting-religious-hatred-182084/#kSt8i6FslPGE4Tew.99 |title=Russian Man Caught Playing Pokemon in Church Could be Sentenced to Prison for 'Inciting Religious Hatred'}}</ref> In 2017, the USCIRF reclassified Russia, as a Tier 1 country thus one of the world's worst violators of religious liberty, recommending that the U.S. government deem Russia a "country of particular concern" under the International Religious Freedom Act. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/sites/default/files/Russia.2017.pdf|title=RUSSIA TIER1 USCIRF RECOMMENDED COUNTRIES OF PARTICULAR CONCERN (CPC)|date=April 26, 2017}}</ref>

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

* [[Roman Catholicism in Russia]]

By official information, there are 68 eparchies of Russian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate).<ref>''Religion and mass media Institute of Russia site''</ref>
+'''Christians in Russia''' constitute by some estimates the largest religion of the country, with nearly 50% of the population identifying as [[Christian]]. The largest tradition is the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. By official information, there are 68 eparchies of Russian Orthodox Church.<ref>''Religion and mass media Institute of Russia site''</ref>
 
-There are from 500,000 to one million so-called [[Old Believers]], who represent an older form of [[Russian Orthodox]] Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms. According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name="USgov"/> In Russia today, about 280,000 associate with over 2200 congregations of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] reports over 20,000 adherents in 126 congregations.
+There are from 500,000 to one million so-called [[Old Believers]], who represent an older form of Russian Orthodox Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms. According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name="USgov"/> In Russia today, about 280,000 associate with over 2200 congregations of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] reports over 20,000 adherents in 126 congregations.
 
 The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates;<ref name="USgov"/> meanwhile, a Russian government survey determined that there are only about 140,000.<ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg</ref><ref>http://sreda.org/arena</ref> There is one Roman Catholic Archdiocese (Mother of God at Moscow) with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" taken effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources and provide records of all meetings.

changed_version:
---

@@ -137,6 +137,9 @@
 By 1939, thousands of Jehovah's Witnesses were already residing in the [[Baltic states]] when the Soviet Union absorbed those formerly independent countries. In the 1940s, the Soviet government forcibly dispersed thousands of Witnesses in a program named [[Operation North]], later described by Dr. N. S. Gordienko, a professor at [[Herzen University]] as having had "just the opposite of what was expected; they wanted to weaken the organization of Jehovah’s Witnesses in the USSR, but in fact they only strengthened it". In the 1950s and 1960s, Jehovah's Witnesses were tracked, infiltrated, harassed, and persecuted by the Soviet government. By 1971, there were more than 4500 Witnesses in the Soviet Union.
 
 When the religion was formally recognized in March 1991, the organization reported 15,987 members in Russia. Beginning in 1993, graduates of [[Watchtower Bible School of Gilead#Gilead School extensions|Gilead Extension School]] in Germany began to be assigned to Russia as missionaries to support the local Witnesses already there. The number of adherents has steadily grown since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. By 2014, Jehovah's Witnesses reported over 170,000 members in Russia.<ref>{{cite book|title=2015 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses|publisher=Watch Tower Society|page=184}}</ref>
+
+On March 23, 2017, the [[Russian News Agency TASS]] reported that Russia's Justice Ministry had suspended the activities of the Administrative Center of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia due to extremist activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tass.com/society/937146|title=Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia suspended over extremism|publisher=}}</ref> On April 4,2017 [[UN Special Rapporteur]] on Freedom of Opinion and Expression [[David Kaye]], UN Special Rapporteur on Freedoms of Peaceful Assembly and Association [[Maina Kiai]], and UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Religion and Belief [[Ahmed Shaheed]] condemned Russia's desire to ban Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title= RUSSIA:Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref> However, on April 20, 2017, The [[Supreme Court of Russia]] issued a verdict upholding the claim from the country’s Justice Ministry that Jehovah’s Witnesses’ activity violated laws on “extremism.” The ruling liquidates the group’s Russian headquarters in St. Petersburg and all of its 395 local religious organizations ordering their property to be seized by the state. This is the first time that a court has ruled that a registered national centralized religious organisation is "extremist" and banned. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title=Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/russian/news/story.asp?newsID=27728|title=UN experts called on Russia to stop lawsuit against Jehovah's Witnesses}}</ref> Many countries and international organizations have spoken out against Russia's religious abuses of Jehovah’s Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.stetson.edu/~psteeves/relnews/170421c.html|title=RUSSIA RELIGION NEWS}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/04/20/russia-court-bans-jehovahs-witnesses|title=Russia: Court Bans Jehovah’s Witnesses}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.csce.gov/international-impact/press-and-media/press-releases/helsinki-commission-condemns-pending-legal |title=HELSINKI COMMISSION CONDEMNS PENDING LEGAL ACTION AGAINST JEHOVAH’S WITNESSES}}</ref> An article in Newsweek stated, “Russia’s decision to ban Jehovah’s Witnesses in the country shows the 'paranoia' of Vladimir Putin’s government, according to the chair of the [[United States Commission on International Religious Freedom]] (USCIRF).”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/jehovahs-witnesses-russia-ban-putin-587179 |title=RUSSIA’S JEHOVAH’S WITNESSES BAN SHOWS ‘PARANOIA’ OF VLADIMIR PUTIN’S GOVERNMENT}}</ref> The [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] warns of the possibility of future genocide in connection with Russia’s ban. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ushmm.org/information/press/press-releases/museum-statement-on-jehovahs-witnesses-in-russia|title=UN experts called on Russia to stop a lawsuit against}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.stetson.edu/~psteeves/relnews/170429a.html|title=Holocaust museum speaks up for Jehovah's Witnesses}}</ref>
+
 {{see also|Persecution of Jehovah's Witnesses#Soviet Union|l1=Persecution of Jehovah's Witnesses in the Soviet Union}}

 == Protestants ==
 {{main|Protestants in Russia}}
 [[File:Peter und Paul Kirche zu Moskau.JPG|right|thumb|Lutheran Church in Moscow]]
-There are [[Evangelical Christian]]s - [[Baptists]] (most numerous), [[Lutheran]]s, [[Pentecostal]]s, [[Adventist]]s,<ref>''Seventh-day Adventist Church Number Two in Russia, Worldwide Faith News, August 1998''</ref> [[Methodist]]s, [[Quaker]]s <ref>''Quakers in Russia site''</ref> and nearly all other known Protestant denominations presented in the country.
+There are [[Evangelical Christian]]s, [[Baptists]] (most numerous), [[Lutheran]]s, [[Pentecostal]]s, [[Adventist]]s,<ref>''Seventh-day Adventist Church Number Two in Russia, Worldwide Faith News, August 1998''</ref> [[Methodist]]s, [[Quaker]]s <ref>''Quakers in Russia site''</ref> and nearly all other known Protestant denominations present in the country. Russia is considered by some observers to experience a Protestant revival in the future.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/world/2011/april/protestant-revival-sweeps-moscow/|title=Moscow Church Spearheads Russia Revival|publisher=|accessdate=14 February 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://biblicalstudies.org.uk/pdf/rss/28-1_093.pdf Protestantism in Postsoviet Russia: An Unacknowledged Triumph]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2002/june10/13.22.html?paging=off|title="Growing Protestants, Catholics Draw Ire"|author=Felix Corley and Geraldine Fagan|work=ChristianityToday.com|accessdate=14 February 2015}}</ref>
 
 By the opinion of Keston Institute, Protestants are widely present and may well outnumber the Orthodox in some places of [[Siberia]]. There are very few "nominal" believers among them: everywhere they preach, pray and often struggle against local bureaucracy to acquire their rights. They are also regarded as respectable, hard-working citizens.<ref>''The religious maelstrom of modern Russia, Timesonline, July 2008''</ref>
 
-Some Protestants (especially at provincial level) report encountering local authorities obstruction of their activities and government restrictions. In April 2007, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] obliged Russian state to pay EUR 10,000 (ten thousand euros) as a non-pecuniary damage for the refusal in registration of the Moscow branch of [[Salvation Army]].
+Some Protestants, especially at provincial level, report encountering local authorities obstruction of their activities and government restrictions. In April 2007, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] obliged Russian state to pay EUR 10,000 (ten thousand euros) as a non-pecuniary damage for the refusal in registration of the Moscow branch of [[Salvation Army]].
 
 Conducted in July - August, 2007, bicycle [[missionary]] expedition of Evangelical Christians Baptists faced, by their report,<ref>''Baptist Union of Russia site, News''</ref> serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia. The [[evangelization]] meetings several times were banned in public parks. The initial goal of the above-mentioned tour was to share the [[Gospel]] with people in towns and villages throughout the country and, by words of UECB President [[Yuri Sipko]], to "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to bring them the message of God’s kingdom."

-
+[[Baptists]] have been historically the largest Protestant group in Russia.

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>
