initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

==See also==
* [[Roman Catholicism in Russia]]
* [[Protestants in Russia]]
* [[Alexander Men]]

==References==
<references/>

==External links==
*[http://www.francis.ru/ Franciscans in Russia]] 
*[http://ru.christiantoday.com/ Christian Today in Russian] 
*[http://jesuschrist.ru/ Christian Portal]
*[http://www.russianbible.net/ Bible in Russian] 
*[http://www.alexandrmen.ru/biogr/english.html Alexandr Men Foundation]
{{Christianity-stub}}
{{Russia-stub}}

-'''Christianity in Russia''' is the most widely professed religion in the country. The largest tradition is the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. According to official sources, there are 68 [[eparchy|eparchies]] of the Russian Orthodox Church.<ref>''Religion and mass media Institute of Russia site''</ref> There are from 500,000 to one million [[Old Believers]], who represents an older form of Russian Orthodox Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms.

According to official sources, there are 170 [[Eparchies and Metropolitanates of the Russian Orthodox Church|eparchies]] of the Russian Orthodox Church, 145 of which are grouped in metropolitanates.<ref>''Religion and mass media Institute of Russia site''</ref> There are from 500,000 to one million [[Old Believers]], who represents an older form of Russian Orthodox Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms.

A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>''US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia, 2006''</ref>
+The [[Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, exceeding government estimates of about 140,000.<ref name="USgov"/><ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg</ref><ref>http://sreda.org/arena</ref> There is one Catholic Archdiocese, Mother of God at Moscow, with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and the Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christians in Russia, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

 ===Jehovah's Witnesses===
 ''Zion's Watch Tower'' (now called ''[[The Watchtower]]'', the primary journal of the [[Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania|Watch Tower Society]]) had subscribers in Russia as early as 1887.<!--Reducing tangential historical detail based only on primary sources and lacking notability... [Early Russian adherent Semyon Kozlitsky, a Russian Orthodox seminary graduate, associated personally with [[Charles Taze Russell]] as early as 1891 and was a member of the [[Bible Student movement]] in Russia, [[Siberia]], and what is now [[Kazakhstan]] until his death in 1935. In the 1920s, ''The Watch Tower'' was published in Russian, and Russian-language congregations were established in the United States and elsewhere.Although there were restrictions in Russia itself, the [[Latvia]] branch translated and printed Russian-language literature and the [[Estonia]] branch broadcast Russian-language radio lectures.]--> In 1935, the Watch Tower Society unsuccessfully attempted to establish a branch office in the [[Soviet Union]] to support members already there. By 1939, thousands of Jehovah's Witnesses were residing in the [[Baltic states]] when the Soviet Union absorbed those formerly independent countries. In the 1940s, the Soviet government forcibly dispersed thousands of Witnesses, in a program named [[Operation North]], later described by Dr. N. S. Gordienko, a professor at [[Herzen University]] as having "just the opposite of what was expected; they wanted to weaken the organization of Jehovah's Witnesses in the USSR, but in fact, they only strengthened it". In the 1950s and 1960s, Jehovah's Witnesses were tracked, infiltrated, harassed, and persecuted by the Soviet government. By 1971, there were more than 4,500 Witnesses in the Soviet Union. When the denomination was formally recognized in March 1991, the organization reported 15,987 members in Russia. Beginning in 1993, Witness missionaries from Germany were assigned to Russia to support the local members. By 2014, Jehovah's Witnesses reported over 170,000 members in Russia.<ref>{{cite book|title=2015 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses|publisher=Watch Tower Society|page=184}}</ref><!--Please provide secondary source(s) for this history-->
 
-On March 23, 2017, the [[Russian News Agency TASS]] reported that Russia's Justice Ministry had suspended the activities of the Administrative Center of Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia due to extremist activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tass.com/society/937146|title=Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia suspended over extremism}}</ref> On April 4, 2017 [[UN Special Rapporteur]] on Freedom of Opinion and Expression [[David Kaye (law professor)|David Kaye]], UN Special Rapporteur on Freedoms of Peaceful Assembly and Association [[Maina Kiai]], and UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Religion and Belief [[Ahmed Shaheed]] condemned Russia's desire to ban Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title= RUSSIA:Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref> However, on April 20, 2017, the [[Supreme Court of Russia]] issued a verdict upholding the claim from the country's Justice Ministry that Jehovah's Witnesses' activity violated laws on "extremism". The ruling liquidates the group's Russian headquarters in St. Petersburg and all of its 395 local religious organizations, ordering their property to be seized by the state. According to [[Forum 18]], this is the first time that a court has ruled that a registered national centralized religious organization is "extremist" and banned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title=Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref><ref>{{Cite  '''Christianity in Russia''' is the most widely professed religion in the country. The largest tradition is the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. According to official sources, there are 170 [[Eparchies and Metropolitanates of the Russian Orthodox Church|eparchies]] of the Russian Orthodox Church, 145 of which are grouped in metropolitanates.<ref>''Religion and mass media Institute of Russia site''</ref> There are from 500,000 to one million [[Old Believers]], who represents an older form of Russian Orthodox Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms.
 
-The [[Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, exceeding government estimates of about 140,000.<ref name="USgov"/><ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg</ref><ref>http://sreda.org/arena</ref> There is one Catholic Archdiocese, Mother of God at Moscow, with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and the Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christians in Russia, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>''US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia, 2006''</ref>

 == Catholic Church ==
 {{main|Catholic Church in Russia}}
-[[File:Храм римско-католический Святого Сердца Господа Иисуса.JPG|thumb|left|Catholic Church in St.Petersburg]]
+[[File:Moscow Immaculate Conception Church asv2019-06 img1.jpg|thumb|[[Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception (Moscow)|Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception]] in Moscow]]
 As of 2008, the [[Catholic Church]] in Russia had one [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mother of God at Moscow|Archdiocese of Mother of God at Moscow]] (headed by Archbishop [[Paolo Pezzi|Pavel Pezzi]]), three dioceses (Saint Clement at [[Saratov]], Saint Joseph at [[Irkutsk]], Transfiguration at [[Novosibirsk]]), one [[Apostolic Exarchate]] and one [[Apostolic Prefecture]] in [[Yuzhno Sakhalinsk]].<ref>''Catholic Dioceses in Russian Federation, GCatholic site''</ref> The Catholic Archbishop of Moscow has voiced his support for religious education in state sponsored schools, citing the examples of other countries.<ref>{{cite web | date= June 19, 2006| title= Russian Catholics back religious education at school  | work= Russian News and Information Agency }}</ref>
 
 Relations with the Russian Orthodox church have been difficult for nearly a millennium, and attempts at re-establishing Catholicism have met with opposition. [[Pope John Paul II]] expressed a desire to visit Russia, but the Russian Orthodox Church resisted.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia   | date= July 3, 2006| title= Putin warns of 'clash of civilisations' at Moscow religious summit  | work= Ecumenical News International }}</ref> In April 2002, Bishop Jerry Mazur of Eastern Siberia was stripped of his visa, forcing the appointment of a new bishop for that diocese.<ref>{{cite web | author=Myers, Steven Lee  | date= July 9, 2002| title= Church Dispute Festers | work= New York Times}}</ref> In 2002, five foreign Catholic priests were denied visas to return to Russia, construction of a new cathedral was blocked in [[Pskov]], and a church in southern Russia was shot at.<ref>{{cite web | author=Kishkovsky, Sophia | date= September 13, 2002| title= Archbishop Appeals To Rights Groups  | work= New York Times }}</ref> On December 25, 2005, Russian Orthodox activists planned to picket outside of Moscow's Catholic Cathedral, but the picket was cancelled. Despite easing of relations with the election of [[Pope Benedict XVI]], there remain issues such as the readiness of the police to protect Catholics and other minorities from persecution.<ref>{{cite web | date= June 7, 2006| title=Whose side are police on? Russian Christians ask | work= Catholic World News }}</ref>

 The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" that took effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources, and provide records of all meetings. initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

* [[Alexander Men]]

@@ -121,7 +121,7 @@
 Translation of the Bible into Russian began in the 16th and 17th centuries. However, the works (by deacon of Posolsky Prikaz Avraamiy Firsov, pastor E. Gluk, and archbishop Methodiy (Smirnov)) were lost during political turbulence and wars.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
 
 ===Russian Bible Society===
-Full-scale translation of the [[Bible]] into Russian began in 1813, with the establishment of the [[Russian Bible Society]]. The complete Bible comprising the [[Old Testament]] and [[New Testament]] was published in 1876. This work, called the [[Russian Synodal Bible]], is widely used by Protestant communities in Russia and former Soviet countries.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 |title=Russian Bible Society, in Russian |access-date=2007-08-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170625224825/http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 |archive-date=2017-06-25 |url-status=dead }}</ref> From 1813 until 1826<!--assuming this is what was meant by the previous awkward wording-->, the Russian Bible Society distributed more than 500,000 Bible-related books in 41 languages. During the 19th and 20th centuries, activities of the Society were stopped by reactionary policies of the Russian government, but were restored in 1990–1991 when Soviet regime restrictions eased.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.biblia.ru/about/history/ |title=History of Russian Bible Society, in Russian |access-date=2007-08-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819222827/http://www.biblia.ru/about/history/ |archive-date=2007-08-19 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
+Full-scale [[Bible translations into Russian|translation of the Bible into Russian]] began in 1813, with the establishment of the [[Russian Bible Society]]. The complete Bible comprising the [[Old Testament]] and [[New Testament]] was published in 1876. This work, called the [[Russian Synodal Bible]], is widely used by Protestant communities in Russia and former Soviet countries.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 |title=Russian Bible Society, in Russian |access-date=2007-08-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170625224825/http://www.biblia.ru/translation/show/?2&start=0 |archive-date=2017-06-25 |url-status=dead }}</ref> From 1813 until 1826<!--assuming this is what was meant by the previous awkward wording-->, the Russian Bible Society distributed more than 500,000 Bible-related books in 41 languages. During the 19th and 20th centuries, activities of the Society were stopped by reactionary policies of the Russian government, but were restored in 1990–1991 when Soviet regime restrictions eased.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.biblia.ru/about/history/ |title=History of Russian Bible Society, in Russian |access-date=2007-08-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819222827/http://www.biblia.ru/about/history/ |archive-date=2007-08-19 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
 
 The opening ceremony of the Russian Bible Society in Moscow was visited by representatives of [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]], [[Catholic]] and Protestant churches, who combined their Bible translation and distribution efforts. The Russian Bible Society produces over 1,000,000 Bible-related books per year. The Society also translates the Bible into the languages and dialects of various ethnic groups throughout Russia.

According to [[Yuri Sipko]], president of the [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]], the goal of the tour was to, "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to convert them." These words are what caused most hostility towards Protestants.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}

 An article in ''[[The Christian Post]]'', discussing the ban on proselytizing stated, "Human rights and religious freedom advocates argue that the law 'doesn't do that much to defend from terrorism and only prevents Christians and others who are not Orthodox from preaching and proselytizing.'"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/russian-man-caught-playing-pokemon-church-sentenced-prison-inciting-religious-hatred-182084/#kSt8i6FslPGE4Tew.99 |title=Russian Man Caught Playing Pokemon in Church Could be Sentenced to Prison for 'Inciting Religious Hatred'|date=30 April 2017 }}</ref> In 2017, the USCIRF reclassified Russia as one of the world's worst violators of religious liberty, recommending that the US government deem Russia a "country of particular concern" under the [[International Religious Freedom Act of 1998|International Religious Freedom Act]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/sites/default/files/Russia.2017.pdf|title=Russia Tier 1 USCIRF Recommended Countries of Particular Concern (CPC)|date=April 26, 2017}}</ref>  Since 2016, Russian Christians face increased restrictions on public and private evangelism as a result of the [[Yarovaya law]].

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

==See also==
* [[Roman Catholicism in Russia]]
* [[Protestants in Russia]]
* [[Alexander Men]]

==References==
<references/>

==External links==

*[http://ru.christiantoday.com/ Christian Today in Russian] 
*[http://jesuschrist.ru/ Christian Portal]
*[http://www.russianbible.net/ Bible in Russian] 
*[http://www.alexandrmen.ru/biogr/english.html Alexandr Men Foundation]
{{Christianity-stub}}
{{Russia-stub}}

[[Category:Christianity by country]]

@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
 [[File:Кафедральный собор Благовещения Пресвятой Богородицы.jpg|thumb|250px|Russian Orthodox [[Annunciation Cathedral, Voronezh|Annunciation Cathedral]] in [[Voronezh]].]]{{Christianity by country}}
 '''Christianity in Russia''' is the most widely professed religion in the country. The largest tradition is the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. According to official sources, there are 170 [[Eparchies and Metropolitanates of the Russian Orthodox Church|eparchies]] of the Russian Orthodox Church, 145 of which are grouped in metropolitanates.<ref>''Religion and mass media Institute of Russia site''</ref> There are from 500,000 to one million [[Old Believers]], who represents an older form of Russian Orthodox Christianity, and who separated from the Orthodox Church in the 17th century as a protest against [[Patriarch Nikon]]'s church reforms.
 
-The [[Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, exceeding government estimates of about 140,000.<ref name="USgov"/><ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg {{Bare URL image|date=March 2022}}</ref><ref>http://sreda.org/arena</ref> There is one Catholic Archdiocese, Mother of God at Moscow, with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and the Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christians in Russia, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>''US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia, 2006''</ref>
+The [[Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, exceeding government estimates of about 140,000.<ref name="USgov"/><ref>http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg {{Bare URL image|date=March 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://sreda.org/arena | title=Главная страница проекта «Арена» : Некоммерческая Исследовательская Служба "Среда" }}</ref> There is one Catholic Archdiocese, Mother of God at Moscow, with three suffragan dioceses (Saint Clement at Saratov, Saint Joseph at Irkutsk, Transfiguration at Novosibirsk) and the Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk.<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/data/countryRU.htm GCatholic Directory]</ref> According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second or third largest group of Christians in Russia, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 1 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>''US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia, 2006''</ref>
 
 Christianity was the religious self-identification of 47.1% of the Russian population in 2012.<ref name="sreda.org">[http://sreda.org/arena Arena - Atlas of Religions and Nationalities in Russia]. 2012 National Survey of Religions in Russia. Sreda.org</ref> Other polls give different results: In the same year 2020 the [[Levada Center]] estimated that 63% of Russians were Christians;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.levada.ru/2020/10/28/vera-v-sverhestestvennoe/|title=ВЕРА В СВЕРХЪЕСТЕСТВЕННОЕ|language=ru|publisher=Levada Center|date=3 November 2020}}</ref> in 2020 the Public Opinion Foundation<ref>{{cite web|title=Об оскорблении религиозных чувств|url=https://fom.ru/TSennosti/14494|publisher=Фонд Общественное Мнение, ФОМ (Public Opinion Foundation)|language=ru|date=21 April 2021}}</ref> estimated that 63% of the population was Christian; in 2011 the [[Pew Research Center]] estimated that 71% of Russians were Christians;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pewforum.org/2017/05/10/religious-belief-and-national-belonging-in-central-and-eastern-europe/|title=Religious Belief and National Belonging in Central and Eastern Europe|publisher=Pew Research Center|date=21 April 2021}}</ref> in 2011 [[Ipsos MORI]] estimated that 69% of Russians were Christians;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fgi-tbff.org/sites/default/files/elfinder/FGIImages/Research/fromresearchtopolicy/ipsos_mori_briefing_pack.pdf|title=Views on globalisation and faith|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117013643/http://www.fgi-tbff.org/sites/default/files/elfinder/FGIImages/Research/fromresearchtopolicy/ipsos_mori_briefing_pack.pdf|archive-date=17 January 2013|publisher=Ipsos MORI|date=5 July 2011|page=40}}</ref> and in 2021 the [[Russian Public Opinion Research Center]] (VCIOM) estimated that ~67% of Russians were Christians.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wciom.ru/analytical-reviews/analiticheskii-obzor/velikii-post-2021/|title=Великий пост — 2021|language=ru|publisher=Levada Center|date=21 April 2021}}</ref>

In June 2016, Russia passed an anti-terrorism law that bans proselytizing and missionary activities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2016/july/russia-ban-evangelism-effect.html |title=Russia Bans on Evangelism is Now in Effect}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/vladimir-putin-russia-foreign-religion-crackdown-498551|title=A New Russian Law Targets Evangelicals and Other 'Foreign' Religions|website=[[Newsweek]]|date=15 September 2016}}</ref> On July 8, 2016 the [[U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom]] (USCIRF) strongly condemned these measures stating, "Under the guise of confronting terrorism, they would grant authorities sweeping powers to curtail civil liberties, including setting broad restrictions on religious practices that would make it very difficult for religious groups to operate."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/news-room/press-releases/russia-uscirf-condemns-enactment-anti-terrorism-laws |title= Russia: USCIRF Condemns Enactment of Anti-Terrorism Laws|date= 21 December 2021}}</ref>

@@ -104,7 +104,7 @@
 ===Jehovah's Witnesses===
 ''Zion's Watch Tower'' (now called ''[[The Watchtower]]'', the primary journal of the [[Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania|Watch Tower Society]]) had subscribers in Russia as early as 1887.<!--Reducing tangential historical detail based only on primary sources and lacking notability... [Early Russian adherent Semyon Kozlitsky, a Russian Orthodox seminary graduate, associated personally with [[Charles Taze Russell]] as early as 1891 and was a member of the [[Bible Student movement]] in Russia, [[Siberia]], and what is now [[Kazakhstan]] until his death in 1935. In the 1920s, ''The Watch Tower'' was published in Russian, and Russian-language congregations were established in the United States and elsewhere.Although there were restrictions in Russia itself, the [[Latvia]] branch translated and printed Russian-language literature and the [[Estonia]] branch broadcast Russian-language radio lectures.]--> In 1935, the Watch Tower Society unsuccessfully attempted to establish a branch office in the [[Soviet Union]] to support members already there. By 1939, thousands of Jehovah's Witnesses were residing in the [[Baltic states]] when the Soviet Union absorbed those formerly independent countries. In the 1940s, the Soviet government forcibly dispersed thousands of Witnesses, in a program named [[Operation North]], later described by Dr. N. S. Gordienko, a professor at [[Herzen University]] as having "just the opposite of what was expected; they wanted to weaken the organization of Jehovah's Witnesses in the USSR, but in fact, they only strengthened it". In the 1950s and 1960s, Jehovah's Witnesses were tracked, infiltrated, harassed, and persecuted by the Soviet government. By 1971, there were more than 4,500 Witnesses in the Soviet Union. When the denomination was formally recognized in March 1991, the organization reported 15,987 members in Russia. Beginning in 1993, Witness missionaries from Germany were assigned to Russia to support the local members. By 2014, Jehovah's Witnesses reported over 170,000 members in Russia.<ref>{{cite book|title=2015 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses|publisher=Watch Tower Society|page=184}}</ref><!--Please provide secondary source(s) for this history-->
 
-On March 23, 2017, the [[Russian News Agency TASS]] reported that Russia's Justice Ministry had suspended the activities of the Administrative Center of Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia due to extremist activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tass.com/society/937146|title=Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia suspended over extremism}}</ref> On April 4, 2017 [[UN Special Rapporteur]] on Freedom of Opinion and Expression [[David Kaye (law professor)|David Kaye]], UN Special Rapporteur on Freedoms of Peaceful Assembly and Association [[Maina Kiai]], and UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Religion and Belief [[Ahmed Shaheed]] condemned Russia's desire to ban Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title= RUSSIA:Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref> However, on April 20, 2017, the [[Supreme Court of Russia]] issued a verdict upholding the claim from the country's Justice Ministry that Jehovah's Witnesses' activity violated laws on "extremism". The ruling liquidates the group's Russian headquarters in St. Petersburg and all of its 395 local religious organizations, ordering their property to be seized by the state. According to [[Forum 18]], this is the first time that a court has ruled that a registered national centralized religious organization is "extremist" and banned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title=Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/russian/news/story.asp?newsID=27728|title=UN experts called on Russia to stop lawsuit against Jehovah's Witnesses}}</ref> Various countries and international organizations have spoken out against Russia's religious abuses of Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.stetson.edu/~psteeves/relnews/170421c.html|title=Russia Religion News|access-date=2017-05-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829034920/http://www2.stetson.edu/~psteeves/relnews/170421c.html|archive-date=2017-08-29|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/04/20/russia-court-bans-jehovahs-witnesses|title=Russia: Court Bans Jehovah's Witnesses}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.csce.gov/international-impact/press-and-media/press-releases/helsinki-commission-condemns-pending-legal |title=Helsinki Commission Condemns Pending Legal Action Against Jehovah's Witnesses}}</ref> An article in Newsweek stated, "Russia's decision to ban Jehovah's Witnesses in the country shows the 'paranoia' of Vladimir Putin's government, according to the chair of the [[United States Commission on International Religious Freedom]] (USCIRF)."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/jehovahs-witnesses-russia-ban-putin-587179 |title=Russia's Jehovah's Witnesses Ban Shows 'Paranoia' of Vladimir Putin's Government}}</ref> The [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] also expressed deep concern over Russia's treatment of Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ushmm.org/information/press/press-releases/museum-statement-on-jehovahs-witnesses-in-russia|title=UN experts called on Russia to stop a lawsuit against}}</ref>
+On March 23, 2017, the [[Russian News Agency TASS]] reported that Russia's Justice Ministry had suspended the activities of the Administrative Center of Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia due to extremist activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tass.com/society/937146|title=Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia suspended over extremism}}</ref> On April 4, 2017 [[UN Special Rapporteur]] on Freedom of Opinion and Expression [[David Kaye (law professor)|David Kaye]], UN Special Rapporteur on Freedoms of Peaceful Assembly and Association [[Maina Kiai]], and UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Religion and Belief [[Ahmed Shaheed]] condemned Russia's desire to ban Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title= RUSSIA:Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref> However, on April 20, 2017, the [[Supreme Court of Russia]] issued a verdict upholding the claim from the country's Justice Ministry that Jehovah's Witnesses' activity violated laws on "extremism". The ruling liquidates the group's Russian headquarters in St. Petersburg and all of its 395 local religious organizations, ordering their property to be seized by the state. According to [[Forum 18]], this is the first time that a court has ruled that a registered national centralized religious organization is "extremist" and banned.<ref>{{Cite  ===Jehovah's Witnesses===
 ''Zion's Watch Tower'' (now called ''[[The Watchtower]]'', the primary journal of the [[Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania|Watch Tower Society]]) had subscribers in Russia as early as 1887.<!--Reducing tangential historical detail based only on primary sources and lacking notability... [Early Russian adherent Semyon Kozlitsky, a Russian Orthodox seminary graduate, associated personally with [[Charles Taze Russell]] as early as 1891 and was a member of the [[Bible Student movement]] in Russia, [[Siberia]], and what is now [[Kazakhstan]] until his death in 1935. In the 1920s, ''The Watch Tower'' was published in Russian, and Russian-language congregations were established in the United States and elsewhere.Although there were restrictions in Russia itself, the [[Latvia]] branch translated and printed Russian-language literature and the [[Estonia]] branch broadcast Russian-language radio lectures.]--> In 1935, the Watch Tower Society unsuccessfully attempted to establish a branch office in the [[Soviet Union]] to support members already there. By 1939, thousands of Jehovah's Witnesses were residing in the [[Baltic states]] when the Soviet Union absorbed those formerly independent countries. In the 1940s, the Soviet government forcibly dispersed thousands of Witnesses, in a program named [[Operation North]], later described by Dr. N. S. Gordienko, a professor at [[Herzen University]] as having "just the opposite of what was expected; they wanted to weaken the organization of Jehovah's Witnesses in the USSR, but in fact, they only strengthened it". In the 1950s and 1960s, Jehovah's Witnesses were tracked, infiltrated, harassed, and persecuted by the Soviet government. By 1971, there were more than 4,500 Witnesses in the Soviet Union. When the denomination was formally recognized in March 1991, the organization reported 15,987 members in Russia. Beginning in 1993, Witness missionaries from Germany were assigned to Russia to support the local members. By 2014, Jehovah's Witnesses reported over 170,000 members in Russia.<ref>{{cite book|title=2015 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses|publisher=Watch Tower Society|page=184}}</ref><!--Please provide secondary source(s) for this history-->

The ruling liquidates the group's Russian headquarters in St. Petersburg and all of its 395 local religious organizations, ordering their property to be seized by the state. According to [[Forum 18]], this is the first time that a court has ruled that a registered national centralized religious organization is "extremist" and banned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title=Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/russian/news/story.asp?newsID=27728|title=UN experts called on Russia to stop lawsuit against Jehovah's Witnesses|date=4 April 2017}}</ref> Various countries and initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

@@ -8,7 +8,7 @@
 
 The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" that took effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources, and provide records of all meetings. In June 2016, Russia passed an anti-terrorism law that bans proselytizing and missionary activities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2016/july/russia-ban-evangelism-effect.html |title=Russia Bans on Evangelism is Now in Effect|work=Christianity Today|first=Sarah|last=Eekhoff Zylstra|date=21 July 2016|access-date=11 June 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/vladimir-putin-russia-foreign-religion-crackdown-498551|title=A New Russian Law Targets Evangelicals and Other 'Foreign' Religions|website=[[Newsweek]]|first=Marc|last=Bennett|date=15 September 2016}}</ref> On July 8, 2016 the [[U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom]] (USCIRF) strongly condemned these measures stating, "Under the guise of confronting terrorism, they would grant authorities sweeping powers to curtail civil liberties, including setting broad restrictions on religious practices that would make it very difficult for religious groups to operate."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/news-room/press-releases/russia-uscirf-condemns-enactment-anti-terrorism-laws |title= Russia: USCIRF Condemns Enactment of Anti-Terrorism Laws|date= 21 December 2021}}</ref>
 <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://freaksflag.blogspot.com/2017/08/they-need-encouragement.html  |title= Christianity in Russia}}</ref>
-An article in ''[[The Christian Post]]'', discussing the ban on proselytizing stated, "Human rights and religious freedom advocates argue that the law 'doesn't do that much to defend from terrorism and only prevents Christians and others who are not Orthodox from preaching and proselytizing.'"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/russian-man-caught-playing-pokemon-church-sentenced-prison-inciting-religious-hatred-182084/#kSt8i6FslPGE4Tew.99 |title=Russian Man Caught Playing Pokemon in Church Could be Sentenced to Prison for 'Inciting Religious Hatred'|work=The Christian Post|first=Anugrah|last=Kumar|date=30 April 2017}}</ref> In 2017, the USCIRF reclassified Russia as one of the world's worst violators of religious liberty, recommending that the US government deem Russia a "country of particular concern" under the [[International Religious Freedom Act of 1998|International Religious Freedom Act]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/sites/default/files/Russia.2017.pdf|title=Russia Tier 1 USCIRF Recommended Countries of Particular Concern (CPC)|date=April 26, 2017}}</ref>  Since 2016, Russian Christians face increased restrictions on public and private evangelism as a result of the [[Yarovaya law]].

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

Sreda.org</ref> Other polls give different results: In the same year 2020 the [[Levada Center]] estimated that 63% of Russians were Christians;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.levada.ru/2020/10/28/vera-v-sverhestestvennoe/|title=ВЕРА В СВЕРХЪЕСТЕСТВЕННОЕ|language=ru|publisher=Levada Center|date=3 November 2020}}</ref> in 2020 the Public Opinion Foundation<ref>{{cite web|title=Об оскорблении религиозных чувств|url=https://fom.ru/TSennosti/14494|publisher=Фонд Общественное Мнение, ФОМ (Public Opinion Foundation)|language=ru|date=21 April 2021}}</ref> estimated that 63% of the population was Christian; in 2011 the [[Pew Research Center]] estimated that 71% of Russians were Christians;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pewforum.org/2017/05/10/religious-belief-and-national-belonging-in-central-and-eastern-europe/|title=Religious Belief and National Belonging in Central and Eastern Europe|publisher=Pew Research Center|date=21 April 2021}}</ref> in 2011 [[Ipsos MORI]] estimated that 69% of Russians were Christians;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fgi-tbff.org/sites/default/files/elfinder/FGIImages/Research/fromresearchtopolicy/ipsos_mori_briefing_pack.pdf|title=Views on globalisation and faith|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117013643/http://www.fgi-tbff.org/sites/default/files/elfinder/FGIImages/Research/fromresearchtopolicy/ipsos_mori_briefing_pack.pdf|archive-date=17 January 2013|publisher=Ipsos MORI|date=5 July 2011|page=40}}</ref> and in 2021 the [[Russian Public Opinion Research Center]] (VCIOM) estimated that ~67% of Russians were Christians.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wciom.ru/analytical-reviews/analiticheskii-obzor/velikii-post-2021/|title=Великий пост — 2021|language=ru|publisher=Levada Center|date=21 April 2021}}</ref>
 
-The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" that took effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including Christian [[church (building)|church]]es, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources, and provide records of all meetings. In June 2016, Russia passed an anti-terrorism law that bans proselytizing and missionary activities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2016/july/russia-ban-evangelism-effect.html |title=Russia Bans on Evangelism is Now in Effect|work=Christianity Today|first=Sarah|last=Eekhoff Zylstra|date=21 July 2016|access-date=11 June 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/vladimir-putin-russia-foreign-religion-crackdown-498551|title=A New Russian Law Targets Evangelicals and Other 'Foreign' Religions|website=[[Newsweek]]|first=Marc|last=Bennett|date=15 September 2016}}</ref> On July 8, 2016 the [[U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom]] (USCIRF) strongly condemned these measures stating, "Under the guise of confronting terrorism, they would grant authorities sweeping powers to curtail civil liberties, including setting broad restrictions on religious practices that would make it very difficult for religious groups to operate."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/news-room/press-releases/russia-uscirf-condemns-enactment-anti-terrorism-laws |title= Russia: USCIRF Condemns Enactment of Anti-Terrorism Laws|date= 21 December 2021}}</ref>

-[[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] had primitive beginnings in the [[Russian Empire]]. [[Joseph Smith]] called [[George J. Adams]] and [[Orson Hyde]] as missionaries to Russia in 1843, 13 years after the Church's creation.<ref name="MormonNewsroom">{{cite web|title=Russia - Facts and Statistics|url=https://newsroom.churchofjesuschrist.org/facts-and-statistics/country/russia|last=Nechiporova|first=Elena|work=Mormon Newsroom|access-date=January 11, 2017}}</ref> However, the death of Smith occurred, and Adams and Hyde never traveled to Russia. The first Russian converts were baptized in the nation in 1895. They were then imprisoned after the [[October Revolution]] in 1918. The Church had some contact with the [[Soviet Union]], such as [[Ezra Taft Benson]] visiting Moscow in 1959 and [[Yuri Dubinin]] visiting [[Utah]] and the [[Brigham Young University]] campus in April 1990. The [[Book of Mormon]] was translated into Russian and published in 1981. The Church was able to reestablish its presence in Russia in 1990,<ref name="ChurchNews">{{cite web|title=Country information: Russia|url=https://www.thechurchnews.com/archive/2010-02-01/country-information-russia-34966|date=February 1, 2010|work=LDS Church News|access-date=January 11, 2017}}</ref> and the Russian government officially recognized the Church in May 1991.<ref name="MormonNewsroom" /> Membership grew in the 1990s and early 2000s,<ref name=":4">Friedlander, Emma. [https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2019/02/26/russian-mormons-search-for-identity-and-acceptance-in-an-american-church-a64574 "Russian Mormons Search for Identity and Acceptance in an American Church"], ''[[The Moscow Times]]'', 26 February 2019. Nelson]] announced at the April [[General Conference (LDS Church)|General Conference]] of the Church that a [[Temple (LDS Church)|temple]] would be constructed in a major city in Russia.{{Cn|date=October 2022}}

 According to Evangelical Christians Baptists who conducted a bicycle [[missionary]] expedition in July – August 2007, they faced serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia.<ref>''Baptist Union of Russia site, News''</ref><!--Please improve this source--> Their services were banned several times in public parks. According to [[Yuri Sipko]], president of the [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]], the goal of the tour was to, "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to convert them." These words are what caused most hostility towards Protestants.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
 
 ==Restorationism==
-Certain Christian denominations consider themselves to have [[Restorationism (Christian primitivism)|restored primitive Christianity]] and do not consider themselves part of Protestantism. Some Orthodox scholars view these denominations as 'totalitarian sects'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ejinsight.com/20170421-russian-court-bans-jehovah-s-witnesses-as-extremist-group|title= Russian court bans Jehovah's Witnesses as extremist group|work=EJ Insight|date=21 April 2017|access-date=13 June 2022}}</ref> The largest of these denominations are [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]].
+Certain Christian denominations consider themselves to have [[Restorationism (Christian primitivism)|restored primitive Christianity]] and do not consider themselves part of Protestantism. Some Orthodox scholars view these denominations as 'totalitarian sects'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ejinsight.com/20170421-russian-court-bans-jehovah-s-witnesses-as-extremist-group|title= Russian court bans Jehovah's Witnesses as extremist group|work=EJ Insight|date=21 April 2017|access-date=13 June 2022}}</ref> The largest of these denominations are [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] and [[the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]].
 
 ===Jehovah's Witnesses===
 ''Zion's Watch Tower'' (now called ''[[The Watchtower]]'', the primary journal of the [[Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania|Watch Tower Society]]) had subscribers in Russia as early as 1887.<!--Reducing tangential historical detail based only on primary sources and lacking notability... [Early Russian adherent Semyon Kozlitsky, a Russian Orthodox seminary graduate, associated personally with [[Charles Taze Russell]] as early as 1891 and was a member of the [[Bible Student movement]] in Russia, [[Siberia]], and what is now [[Kazakhstan]] until his death in 1935. In the 1920s, ''The Watch Tower'' was published in Russian, and Russian-language congregations were established in the United States and elsewhere.Although there were restrictions in Russia itself, the [[Latvia]] branch translated and printed Russian-language literature and the [[Estonia]] branch broadcast Russian-language radio lectures.]--> In 1935, the Watch Tower Society unsuccessfully attempted to establish a branch office in the [[Soviet Union]] to support members already there. By 1939, thousands of Jehovah's Witnesses were residing in the [[Baltic states]] when the Soviet Union absorbed those formerly independent countries. In the 1940s, the Soviet government forcibly dispersed thousands of Witnesses, in a program named [[Operation North]], later described by Dr. N. S. Gordienko, a professor at [[Herzen University]] as having "just the opposite of what was expected; they wanted to weaken the organization of Jehovah's Witnesses in the USSR, but in fact, they only strengthened it". In the 1950s and 1960s, Jehovah's Witnesses were tracked, infiltrated, harassed, and persecuted by the Soviet government. By 1971, there were more than 4,500 Witnesses in the Soviet Union. When the denomination was formally recognized in March 1991, the organization reported 15,987 members in Russia. Beginning in 1993, Witness missionaries from Germany were assigned to Russia to support the local members. By 2014, Jehovah's Witnesses reported over 170,000 members in Russia.<ref>{{cite book|title=2015 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses|publisher=Watch Tower Society|page=184}}</ref><!--Please provide secondary source(s) for this history-->
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is a **case fix** in the term "the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints," where "The" was changed to "the."

Not Weaponised. The change is purely grammatical and does not alter the meaning or introduce any politically charged language related to cultural heritage.

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

By 2014, Jehovah's Witnesses reported over 170,000 members in Russia.<ref>{{cite book|title=2015 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses|publisher=Watch Tower Society|page=184}}</ref><!--Please provide secondary source(s) for this history-->
 
-On March 23, 2017, the [[Russian News Agency TASS]] reported that Russia's Justice Ministry had suspended the activities of the Administrative Center of Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia due to extremist activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tass.com/society/937146|title=Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia suspended over extremism|work=TASS|date=March 23, 2017|access-date=June 14, 2022}}</ref> On April 4, 2017 [[UN Special Rapporteur]] on Freedom of Opinion and Expression [[David Kaye (law professor)|David Kaye]], UN Special Rapporteur on Freedoms of Peaceful Assembly and Association [[Maina Kiai]], and UN Special Rapporteur on [[Freedom of religion|Freedom of Religion]] and Belief [[Ahmed Shaheed]] condemned Russia's desire to ban Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title= RUSSIA:Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref> However, on April 20, 2017, the [[Supreme Court of Russia]] issued a verdict upholding the claim from the country's Justice Ministry that Jehovah's Witnesses' activity violated laws on "extremism". The ruling liquidates the group's Russian headquarters in St. Petersburg and all of its 395 local religious organizations, ordering their property to be seized by the state. According to [[Forum 18]], this is the first time that a court has ruled that a registered national centralized religious organization is "extremist" and banned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title=Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/russian/news/story.asp?newsID=27728|title=UN experts called on Russia to stop lawsuit against Jehovah's Witnesses|date=4 April 2017}}</ref> Various countries and international organizations have spoken out against Russia's religious abuses of Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.stetson.edu/~psteeves/relnews/170421c.html|title=Russia Religion News|access-date=2017-05-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829034920/http://www2.stetson.edu/~psteeves/relnews/170421c.html|archive-date=2017-08-29|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

* [[Roman Catholicism in Russia]]
* [[Protestants in Russia]]
* [[Alexander Men]]

 ===Jehovah's Witnesses===
 ''Zion's Watch Tower'' (now called ''[[The Watchtower]]'', the primary journal of the [[Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania|Watch Tower Society]]) had subscribers in Russia as early as 1887.<!--Reducing tangential historical detail based only on primary sources and lacking notability... [Early Russian adherent Semyon Kozlitsky, a Russian Orthodox seminary graduate, associated personally with [[Charles Taze Russell]] as early as 1891 and was a member of the [[Bible Student movement]] in Russia, [[Siberia]], and what is now [[Kazakhstan]] until his death in 1935. In the 1920s, ''The Watch Tower'' was published in Russian, and Russian-language congregations were established in the United States and elsewhere.Although there were restrictions in Russia itself, the [[Latvia]] branch translated and printed Russian-language literature and the [[Estonia]] branch broadcast Russian-language radio lectures.]--> In 1935, the Watch Tower Society unsuccessfully attempted to establish a branch office in the [[Soviet Union]] to support members already there. By 1939, thousands of Jehovah's Witnesses were residing in the [[Baltic states]] when the Soviet Union absorbed those formerly independent countries. In the 1940s, the Soviet government forcibly dispersed thousands of Witnesses, in a program named [[Operation North]], later described by Dr. N. S. Gordienko, a professor at [[Herzen University]] as having "just the opposite of what was expected; they wanted to weaken the organization of Jehovah's Witnesses in the USSR, but in fact, they only strengthened it". In the 1950s and 1960s, Jehovah's Witnesses were tracked, infiltrated, harassed, and persecuted by the Soviet government. By 1971, there were more than 4,500 Witnesses in the Soviet Union. When the denomination was formally recognized in March 1991, the organization reported 15,987 members in Russia. Beginning in 1993, Witness missionaries from Germany were assigned to Russia to support the local members. By 2014, Jehovah's Witnesses reported over 170,000 members in Russia.<ref>{{cite book|title=2015 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses|publisher=Watch Tower Society|page=184}}</ref><!--Please provide secondary source(s) for this history-->

By 2014, Jehovah's Witnesses reported over 170,000 members in Russia.<ref>{{cite book|title=2015 Yearbook of Jehovah's Witnesses|publisher=Watch Tower Society|page=184}}</ref><!--Please provide secondary source(s) for this history-->
 
-On March 23, 2017, the [[Russian News Agency TASS]] reported that Russia's Justice Ministry had suspended the activities of the Administrative Center of Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia due to extremist activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tass.com/society/937146|title=Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia suspended over extremism|work=TASS|date=March 23, 2017|access-date=June 14, 2022}}</ref> On April 4, 2017 [[UN Special Rapporteur]] on Freedom of Opinion and Expression [[David Kaye (law professor)|David Kaye]], UN Special Rapporteur on Freedoms of Peaceful Assembly and Association [[Maina Kiai]], and UN Special Rapporteur on [[Freedom of religion|Freedom of Religion]] and Belief [[Ahmed Shaheed]] condemned Russia's desire to ban Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title= RUSSIA:Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref> However, on April 20, 2017, the [[Supreme Court of Russia]] issued a verdict upholding the claim from the country's Justice Ministry that Jehovah's Witnesses' activity violated laws on "extremism". The ruling liquidates the group's Russian headquarters in St. Petersburg and all of its 395 local religious organizations, ordering their property to be seized by the state. According to [[Forum 18]], this is the first time that a court has ruled that a registered national centralized religious organization is "extremist" and banned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2274|title=Jehovah's Witnesses banned, property confiscated}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/russian/news/story.asp?newsID=27728|title=UN experts called on Russia to stop lawsuit against Jehovah's Witnesses|date=4 April 2017}}</ref> Various countries and international organizations have spoken out against Russia's religious abuses of Jehovah's Witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.stetson.edu/~psteeves/relnews/170421c.html|title=Russia Religion initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -99,7 +99,7 @@
 According to Evangelical Christians Baptists who conducted a bicycle [[missionary]] expedition in July – August 2007, they faced serious obstacles and suspicious attitude from local authorities in several regions of Russia.<ref>''Baptist Union of Russia site, News''</ref><!--Please improve this source--> Their services were banned several times in public parks. According to [[Yuri Sipko]], president of the [[Union of Evangelical Christians-Baptists of Russia]], the goal of the tour was to, "fight their way through on foot or on bicycles to reach even the most remote village and the most despairing person in order to convert them." These words are what caused most hostility towards Protestants.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
 
 The Russian "law on non-governmental organizations" that took effect in April 2007 requires [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs), including [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] churches, to register with state agencies, list their funding sources, and provide records of all meetings. In June 2016, Russia passed an anti-terrorism law that bans proselytizing and missionary activities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2016/july/russia-ban-evangelism-effect.html |title=Russia Bans on Evangelism is Now in Effect|work=Christianity Today|first=Sarah|last=Eekhoff Zylstra|date=21 July 2016|access-date=11 June 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/vladimir-putin-russia-foreign-religion-crackdown-498551|title=A New Russian Law Targets Evangelicals and Other 'Foreign' Religions|website=[[Newsweek]]|first=Marc|last=Bennett|date=15 September 2016}}</ref> On July 8, 2016, the [[U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom]] (USCIRF) strongly condemned these measures stating, "Under the guise of confronting terrorism, they would grant authorities sweeping powers to curtail civil liberties, including setting broad restrictions on religious practices that would make it very difficult for religious groups to operate."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/news-room/press-releases/russia-uscirf-condemns-enactment-anti-terrorism-laws |title= Russia: USCIRF Condemns Enactment of Anti-Terrorism Laws|date= 21 December 2021}}</ref>
-<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://freaksflag.blogspot.com/2017/08/they-need-encouragement.html  |title= Christianity in Russia}}</ref>
+<ref>{{Cite web  |url=https://freaksflag.blogspot.com/2017/08/they-need-encouragement.html  |title=Christianity in Russia  }}{{Dead link|date=December 2024 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
 An article in ''[[The Christian Post]]'', discussing the ban on proselytizing stated, "Human rights and religious freedom advocates argue that the law 'doesn't do that much to defend from terrorism and only prevents Christians and others who are not Orthodox from preaching and proselytizing.'"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/russian-man-caught-playing-pokemon-church-sentenced-prison-inciting-religious-hatred-182084/#kSt8i6FslPGE4Tew.99 |title=Russian Man Caught Playing Pokémon in Church Could be Sentenced to Prison for 'Inciting Religious Hatred'|work=The Christian Post|first=Anugrah|last=Kumar|date=30 April 2017}}</ref> In 2017, the USCIRF reclassified Russia as one of the world's worst violators of religious liberty, recommending that the US government deem Russia a "country of particular concern" under the [[International Religious Freedom Act of 1998|International Religious Freedom Act]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/sites/default/files/Russia.2017.pdf|title=Russia Tier 1 USCIRF Recommended Countries of Particular Concern (CPC)|date=April 26, 2017}}</ref> Since 2016, Russian Christians face increased restrictions on public and private evangelism as a result of the [[Yarovaya law]].

initial_version:
{{christianity}}
'''''Christians in Russia''''' constitute by some estimations nearly 72% of total population ([[2006]]). Approximately 70% of the country residents consider themselves [[Russian Orthodox]] Christians, although the vast majority are not regular churchgoers.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

According to the Slavic Center for Law and Justice, [[Protestantism|Protestant]]s make up the second largest group of Christian believers, with approximately 3,500 organizations and more than 2 million followers. A large number of missionaries operating in the country are from Protestant denominations.<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>

The [[Roman Catholic Church]] estimates that there are from 600,000 to 1.5 million Catholics in the country, figures that also exceeded government estimates.
<ref name=USgov>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71403.htm US State Department Religious Freedom Report on Russia]</ref>
